Title: Trump administration finds Columbia violated Jewish students' civil rights
Description: <p><a href="https://www.axios.com/2024/05/03/columbia-investigation-education-department" target="_blank">Columbia University</a> violated federal civil-rights law by "acting with deliberate indifference towards student-on-student harassment of Jewish students" from <a href="https://www.axios.com/2024/10/07/october-7-anniversary-israel-hamas-gaza-war" target="_blank">Oct. 7</a>, 2023, through the present, a Trump administration investigation found Thursday.</p><p><strong>The big picture: </strong>The college was last year an epicenter for <a href="https://www.axios.com/2024/04/30/columbia-protestors-expulsion-occupied-building" target="_self">students protesting</a> the <a href="https://www.axios.com/world/israel" target="_blank">Israel</a>-Hamas war and the <a href="https://www.axios.com/politics-policy/donald-trump" target="_blank">Trump</a> administration announced in March it was <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/07/trump-columbia-antisemitism-protests-federal-money" target="_blank">pulling some $400 million</a> in federal grants and contracts over its dissatisfaction at Columbia's response to antisemitism allegations.</p><hr><ul><li>"We understand this finding is part of our ongoing discussions with the government," a Columbia spokesperson said in an emailed statement.</li><li>"Columbia is deeply committed to combatting antisemitism and all forms of harassment and discrimination on our campus. We take these issues seriously and will work with the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Education to address them."</li></ul><p><strong>Details: </strong>An investigation found that Columbia violated Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which protects against discrimination on the basis of race, color, or national origin, per Thursday <a href="https://www.hhs.gov/press-room/ocr-columbia-violates-federal-civil-rights-law.html" target="_blank">statement</a> from the Department of Health and Human Services' civil-rights office.</p><ul><li>Among the findings were that Columbia allegedly failed to "investigate or punish vandalism in its classrooms, which include the repeated drawing of swastikas and other universally recognized hate images."</li><li>No fresh action against Columbia was announced following the investigation findings.</li></ul><p><strong>What they're saying: </strong>"The findings carefully document the hostile environment Jewish students at Columbia University have had to endure for over 19 months, disrupting their education, safety, and well-being," said Anthony Archeval, Acting Director of the Office for Civil Rights at HHS, in a statement. </p><ul><li>"We encourage Columbia University to work with us to come to an agreement that reflects meaningful changes that will truly protect Jewish students."</li></ul><p><strong>Zoom out: </strong>The Trump administration <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/17/universities-trump-harvard-columbia" target="_blank">has targeted</a> educational institutions, <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/16/harvard-columbia-demands-trump-vision-universities-influence" target="_self">pressuring universities</a> to meet its demands or risk losing funding and tax-exempt status, Axios' <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/22/harvard-warning-universities-noem-dhs" target="_blank">Sareen Habeshian notes</a>.</p><p><strong>Go deeper: </strong><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/22/harvard-trump-international-students-dhs" target="_blank">Trump admin nixes Harvard's ability to enroll international students</a></p>

Title: Democrats to vote in June on whether to redo election of David Hogg as DNC vice chair
Description: <p>The Democratic National Committee will vote in June on whether to hold a redo of the election of <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/13/david-hogg-dnc-vice-chair-democrats" target="_blank">David Hogg</a> and Pennsylvania state Rep. <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/philadelphia/2024/09/26/pennsylvania-auditor-general-election-kenyatta-defoor" target="_blank">Malcolm Kenyatta</a> as vice chairs, per a Thursday evening DNC meeting.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>Kalyn Free, a losing candidate in February's vice chair race, claims the pair was elected under a flawed tabulation process, but Hogg alleges it's linked to his efforts to reform the party that include plans to spend <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/18/house-democrats-david-hogg-primary-dnc" target="_blank">$20 million</a> to <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/25/house-democrats-jeffries-pelosi-primary-challenge" target="_self">primary older Democratic</a> Congress members. </p><hr><p><strong>Driving the news: </strong>The DNC Rules and Bylaws Committee at a <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?app=desktop&amp;v=95EJq4MH8cE" target="_blank">virtual</a> meeting determined that a vote should be held electronically from June 9-11.</p><ul><li>Hogg said at the meeting the move "sends a horrible message to the public about our inability to run elections."</li><li>If Democrats were to redo this election, "it truly just sends a horrible message that we really do not want out there at the at this moment," he said. "That's why I believe that it should not go forward, and if it does, it does, it should not be done electronically or over mail."</li><li>Kenyatta said at the meeting that he "fundamentally" believes that the election was fair.</li></ul><p><strong>What's next: </strong>If most DNC members vote to redo the election, there will be an electronic vote for a male vice chair on June 12-14 and an any gender vote for a second vice chair, according to a timeline shared at the meeting.</p><p><strong>Go deeper: </strong><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/18/house-democrats-david-hogg-primary-dnc" target="_blank">House Democrats fume at David Hogg's plan to oust lawmakers</a></p><p><em>Editor's note: Axios' Andrew Solender contributed reporting.</em></p>

Title: Scoop: Primary challengers circle Thomas Massie after Trump-defying vote
Description: <p>President Trump's political operation has been fielding calls from Republicans interested in waging a primary challenge to Kentucky Rep. <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/nrcc-trump-hudson-republican-primaries" target="_blank">Thomas Massie</a>, according to a person familiar with the talks.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>The conversations are evidence that Trump ‚Äî and his <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/10/trump-maga-inc-power-fundraising" target="_blank">$500 million political apparatus</a> ‚Äî is actively entertaining the best way to back a primary opponent against Massie, who has drawn Trump's ire for voting against his "one big, beautiful bill."</p><hr><ul><li>"Massie is about to be in the fight of his life," said Kentucky-based GOP strategist Jake Cox. "Just wait until he sees the money a Trump-backed candidate can raise simply from the President saying their name into a camera or opening up his email list."</li><li>Two possible primary challengers being mentioned in Kentucky Republican circles are state Sen. Aaron Reed and state Rep. Kimberly Moser.</li><li>A statewide Kentucky GOP official tells Axios: "Massie has had weak primary opponents in previous cycles and made mincemeat of them, but I think this time is different. Supporting Trump is the No. 1 ‚Äî and sometimes the only ‚Äî issue in GOP primaries at the moment."</li></ul><p><strong>What they're saying:</strong> Trump has privately wondered what the point is of having a Republican in Massie's seat if "they're going to vote with Democrats and trash Republicans all the time."</p><ul><li>Trump's anger boiled on Tuesday, when he told reporters in the Capitol that the congressman should be "<a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/trump-house-republicans-medicaid-salt" target="_blank">voted out of office</a>."</li><li>The president's political lieutenants piled on. "Some guys just prefer to be in the minority," White House deputy chief of staff James Blair said of Massie on X.</li><li>When asked during a Thursday briefing whether Trump believed ‚Äî as well as Rep. Warren Davidson (R-Ohio), who also voted "no" ‚Äî should be primaried, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt responded: "I believe he does and I believe he does not like to see grandstanders in Congress."</li></ul><p><strong>The background: </strong>Massie and Trump have clashed for years.</p><ul><li>In 2019, Massie joined House Democrats in opposing Trump's declaration of a national emergency at the southern border.</li><li>After Massie opposed a COVID relief package in 2020, Trump called on the congressman to be thrown "out of the Republican Party."</li><li>Massie was one of six House Republicans to endorse Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis over Trump during the 2024 Republican presidential primary.</li><li>After Massie opposed a Trump-backed government spending bill in March, Trump wrote on Truth Social that the congressman was a "GRANDSTANDER."</li></ul><p><strong>Behind the scenes: </strong>During the transition, Trump privately asked DeSantis for advice on how to deal with Massie.</p><ul><li>"Give him raw milk," DeSantis said, referring to one of Massie's <a href="https://massie.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=395642" target="_blank">legislative priorities</a>, according to a person briefed on the conversation.</li></ul><p><strong>The other side: </strong>Massie told Axios he was skeptical Trump allies would find a strong candidate to run against him. </p><ul><li>Massie noted he had easily fended off primary challenges in the last three elections and said his private polling showed him popular in his conservative central Kentucky district.</li><li>"If somebody¬†got in this race and they were a reasonable person, not crazy to run against me, I would call them up and say: 'You know what you should do before you dedicate the next year and a half of your life to getting your a** kicked? You should do a poll,'" Massie said.</li><li>Massie also said Trump's attacks on him were helping him fundraise, pointing out he had raised $47,000 this week and had a series of donor events lined up in California next week.</li><li>The congressman's allies say his independent streak endears him to voters.</li></ul><p><strong>The intrigue: </strong>Massie said he spoke to Trump a few weeks before the election and a few weeks after, but not since. After Massie's mother passed away in June 2024, Trump left him a voicemail expressing his condolences, Massie said.</p><ul><li>During the call after the election, Massie told Trump he would be interested in serving as his agriculture secretary, an idea Trump passed on. </li><li>"I would have taken it," Massie said.</li></ul>

Title: "You don't have to die in this place": House Dems want age reckoning after Connolly's death
Description: <p>Some younger House Democrats are preparing to push for a long-delayed, caucus-wide intervention on age after the tragic passing of yet another one of <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/gerry-connolly-dies-oversight-committee-virginia" target="_blank">their septuagenarian colleagues</a>, Axios has learned.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>The impacts of the party's aging membership were keenly felt Thursday when House Republicans <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/22/house-passes-trumps-big-beautiful-bill" target="_blank">passed their sweeping tax cut bill</a> by just a single vote, 215 to 214.</p><hr><ul><li>Several House Democrats argued that vacancies created by the deaths of Reps. Gerry Connolly (D-Va.), <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/13/raul-grijalva-dies-cancer-77" target="_blank">Ra√∫l Grijalva</a> (D-Ariz.) and <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/05/sylvester-turner-house-democrat-texas-dies" target="_blank">Sylvester Turner</a> (D-Texas), all in their 70s, may have been outcome-determinative.</li><li>"You see where we are, we can't afford to lose anymore members. ... We're down three people because they passed away," one lawmaker told Axios just off the floor as the House was voting on the bill.</li><li>Said another ahead of the vote: "The tragic reality is, when ... this vote passes and the difference is the number of members who passed away this Congress, I think it's going to really infuriate many of our supporters."</li></ul><p><strong>By the numbers: </strong>The eight members of Congress who have died in office since November 2022 were all Democrats, with an average age of 75.</p><ul><li>A half dozen of those deaths were just in the 13 months since last April.</li><li>Grijalva's seat won't be filled until a <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/phoenix/2025/03/26/democratic-candidates-lining-up-for-cd7-special-election-to-replace-grijalva" target="_blank">special election</a> is held in late September. Texas' Republican Gov. Greg Abbott has scheduled the election for Turner's seat <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/houston/2025/04/08/bayou-buzz" target="_blank">on Nov. 4</a>, to the fury of Democrats.</li><li>Some Democrats fear Virginia's Republican governor may similarly drag his feet on scheduling a contest to replace Connolly.</li></ul><p><strong>Between the lines: </strong>Of the House's 10 oldest members, seven are Democrats, Axios' <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/congress-ages-gerontocracy-members-gerry-connolly" target="_blank">April Rubin reported</a>.</p><ul><li>"Some folks have given their life to this place, and we're so grateful and commend them for it ‚Äî you don't have to die in this place," the first House Democrat said. </li><li>"I definitely think that someone in leadership needs to have some hard conversations and say ‚Ä¶ 'you don't [have to] keep doing this.'"</li></ul><p><strong>State of play: </strong>In interviews with a dozen House Democrats on Wednesday and Thursday, many said the time for those difficult discussions has come.</p><ul><li>Most spoke on the condition of anonymity to offer candid thoughts about a highly sensitive topic without facing backlash from their colleagues.</li><li>"This is something that Democrats come up to me [and ask about] all the time, everywhere I go, like, 'You guys need a fresh face. A fresh message and a fresh face,'" said a third House Democrat.</li><li>A fourth told Axios it's nothing personal to older members, but "the people don't own the seats, and we just look so f**king out of touch."</li><li>"I think this could force a conversation," a fifth House Democrat said of Connolly's passing on Wednesday.</li></ul><p><strong>What to watch: </strong>It is not yet clear what reforms younger Democrats will pursue, though several floated a renewed push for committee leadership term limits as a way to incentivize older members to retire.</p><ul><li>Republicans "don't have seniority over there. We do. That could be something that gets discussed," the fifth House Democrat said.</li><li>"The incentives, on our side, cause people to be here a long time," said a sixth lawmaker. "There's a conversation to be had there."</li><li>A seventh told Axios that when committee term limits were instituted in their state legislature, "I think it ended up being for the better. ... It was exciting to be on a team where it felt like everyone had an equitable shot."</li></ul><p><strong>The intrigue: </strong>Rep. Bill Foster (D-Ill.), Democrats' <a href="https://www.axios.com/2024/11/22/house-democrats-leaders-age" target="_blank">long-suffering champion</a> of committee term limits, said he is handing off the baton as he nears 70 in an attempt to lead by example.</p><ul><li>"I've passed the torch to the next generation. It was a little bit ironic that it was a couple of boomers arguing for generational change," the 69-year-old, who was first elected to Congress in 2008, told Axios.</li><li>The fourth House Democrat who spoke anonymously said there are "a bunch of us" planning to make that push ‚Äî but that "it can't happen right now" in the immediate wake of Connolly's death.</li></ul><p><strong>Yes, but: </strong>House Democrats' older members aren't about to concede anything.</p><ul><li>More than half of the 30 House Democrats over 75 years old <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/15/house-democrats-age-members-reelection-biden" target="_blank">are running again</a>, and many attest to their vigorous health. A sizable portion of them are facing or are expected to face <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/24/house-democrats-primary-challenges" target="_blank">primary challenges</a>.</li><li>Reps. Stephen Lynch (D-Mass.), 70, and Kweisi Mfume (D-Md.), 76, have expressed interest in <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/30/democrats-connolly-aoc-crockett-lynch-oversight" target="_blank">running to replace Connolly</a> as the ranking member of the House Oversight Committee. </li><li>They may face 47-year-old <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/06/robert-garcia-aoc-oversight-committee-democrats" target="_blank">Robert Garcia</a> (D-Calif.), a member of House Democratic leadership who could try to use his strong relationships with colleagues to overcome his relative lack of seniority.</li></ul><p><strong>The bottom line: </strong>That this issue is bubbling up to the surface amid <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/22/biden-original-sin-book-oversight-committee" target="_blank">new revelations about President Biden's health</a> only gives it more urgency, lawmakers said.</p><ul><li>"It's important. It's just more symbolically important. We've got Joe Biden hanging over here ... like a huge albatross," said the third House Democrat.</li><li>"Then you add to this that the face of Congress just seems older. ... People keep hearing about all these older people who we have here and are like, 'Wait, what?'"</li></ul>
