normal, NOAA meteorologists said Thursday in their annual forecast.</p><p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> The outlook comes as the Trump administration explores downsizing or <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/trump-fema-hurricane-season-disasters" target="_blank">dismantling FEMA</a>, the federal agency tasked with responding to storms and other natural disasters.</p><hr><p><strong>The big picture:</strong> This year is likely to have 13 to 19 named storms, with three to five of those being Category 3 hurricanes or stronger, according to National Weather Service director Ken Graham.</p><ul><li>This season isn't expected to be as active as <a href="https://www.noaa.gov/news-release/noaa-predicts-above-normal-2024-atlantic-hurricane-season" target="_blank">last year's</a>, he said, but it only takes one takes one storm to hit where you live. </li><li>Colorado State University's forecast last month lines up with NOAA's ‚Äî <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/tampa-bay/2025/04/03/2025-hurricane-season-storm-activity-forecast" target="_blank">"above-normal" activity</a> with 17 named storms, nine hurricanes and four major hurricanes. </li></ul><p><strong>Zoom in: </strong>In response to questions about staffing cuts, Graham and acting NOAA administrator Laura Grimm told reporters Thursday they are confident in their forecasting ability for the season.</p><ul><li>Graham also told Axios that NWS this year is seeing the same level of interest in weather briefings from their federal partners, including FEMA, as compared to last year, despite those cutbacks.</li><li>"We are fully staffed at the Hurricane Center, and we definitely are ready to go," Grimm said.</li></ul><p><strong>Zoom out:</strong> Michael Brennan, director of the National Hurricane Center, is slated to give his annual congressional briefing Thursday afternoon about hurricane season preparedness.</p><p><strong>Meanwhile, </strong>U.S. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem earlier this week reiterated the administration's priority to shift FEMA's responsibilities to states.</p><ul><li>"Our goal is that states should manage their emergencies and we come in and support them," she said at Tuesday's meeting to reform FEMA, according to <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/fema-should-take-new-name-states-should-bear-costs-dhs-head-noem-says-2025-05-20/" target="_blank">Reuters</a>.</li><li>President Trump ‚Äî <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/Fiscal-Year-2026-Discretionary-Budget-Request.pdf" target="_blank">whose budget</a> proposes more than $646 million in cuts to FEMA ‚Äî has signed executive orders aimed at <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/council-to-assess-the-federal-emergency-management-agency/" target="_blank">streamlining the federal disaster agency</a> and <a href="https://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/documents/executive-order-14239-achieving-efficiency-through-state-and-local-preparedness" target="_blank">shifting more responsibility</a> to the states, Axios' Natalie Daher writes. Fully eliminating FEMA would require an act of Congress.</li><li>Other <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/02/28/noaa-layoffs-threaten-weather-climate-forecasts" target="_blank">staffing cuts</a> and <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/27/noaa-merges-climate-prediction-center" target="_self">changes</a> being made to NOAA and its agencies, including the NWS, are raising concerns about <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/20/noaa-federal-layoffs-weather-forecasting-threat" target="_self">reduced forecasting abilities</a>.</li></ul><p><strong>Between the lines: </strong>David Richardson, the current acting head of FEMA as of earlier this month, has no experience managing natural disasters and acknowledged in private meetings that the agency doesn't yet have a fully formed hurricane response plan, the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/politics/policy/fema-hurricane-season-no-plan-39042ee6?mod=hp_lead_pos2" target="_blank">Wall Street Journal reported</a>.</p><ul><li>"As FEMA transforms to a smaller footprint, the intent for this hurricane season is not well understood," warned an internal review <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2025/05/15/politics/fema-review-concerns-hurricane-season" target="_blank">obtained by CNN</a> last week. "Thus FEMA is not ready."</li><li>Since that leak, FEMA appears to be taking steps to bolster its disaster response efforts, according to <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2025/05/21/politics/fema-hurricane-prep-kristi-noem" target="_blank">CNN</a>.</li></ul><p><strong>Threat level:</strong> Louisiana, Texas and Florida could face the greatest financial burdens in a world with less federal relief assistance, Axios' Alex Fitzpatrick writes, based on <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/new-orleans/2025/04/16/louisiana-fema-payouts-hurricanes-season" target="_blank">new analysis</a> from the Carnegie Disaster Dollar Database.</p><ul><li>Louisiana residents also have received the <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/new-orleans/2024/10/09/fema-money-louisiana-assistance-hurricanes" target="_blank">most FEMA direct assistance</a> since 2015, according to Carnegie.</li><li>Louisiana's congressional delegation <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/new-orleans/2025/05/09/fema-chief-fired-cameron-hamilton-louisiana" target="_blank">expressed concern</a> earlier this month to Axios about the federal government's ability to respond to a large-scale disaster.</li></ul><p><strong>The intrigue:</strong> NOAA's leadership gave the forecast in Gretna, a suburb of New Orleans, in recognition of the 20th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina's devastation in the region.</p><p><strong>How it works: </strong>Atlantic hurricane season officially starts June 1, but storms can form any time.</p><ul><li>NHC began its daily tropical outlook May 15, and so far all has been quiet in the Gulf, Caribbean and Atlantic.</li><li>Historically, the most active period for strong storms in the Gulf and the Atlantic is August and September.</li></ul><p><strong>What's next:</strong> Authorities urge residents to prepare now for the season by <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/new-orleans/2023/05/31/hurricane-emergency-kit-checklist" target="_blank">gathering emergency supplies</a>, <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/new-orleans/2024/05/31/preparation-checklist-hurricane-season-home-vehicle-pets" target="_blank">preparing their home</a> for storms and making an <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/new-orleans/2024/06/27/hurricane-evacuation-plans-contraflow" target="_blank">evacuation plan</a>.</p><p><em>Editor's note: This story has been updated with additional information.</em></p><h2>Go deeper:</h2><ul><li><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/13/fema-state-funding-trump-executive-order" target="_blank">These states would suffer the most without FEMA</a></li><li><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/trump-fema-hurricane-season-disasters" target="_blank">Trump's FEMA risks "flying blind" into hurricane season</a></li><li><a href="https://www.axios.com/local/new-orleans/2024/06/27/hurricane-evacuation-plans-contraflow" target="_blank">Contraflow is dying as a New Orleans hurricane evacuation option</a></li></ul>

Title: 2 Israeli Embassy staff killed in shooting near Capital Jewish Museum in D.C., officials say
Description: <p>Two <a href="https://www.axios.com/world/israel" target="_blank">Israeli</a> Embassy staff were fatally shot at close range while leaving an event Wednesday night at the Capital Jewish Museum in D.C., the embassy's spokesperson in Washington, Tal Naim Cohen, told Axios.</p><p><strong>The big picture: </strong>The suspect, who was apprehended by a museum security guard minutes after the shooting, chanted "free Palestine" as he was arrested, Metropolitan Police Chief Pamela Smith said at a press <a href="https://www.facebook.com/MayorMurielBowser/videos/1221158726321259/" target="_blank">briefing</a>.</p><ul><li>The victims were identified by the <a href="https://x.com/IsraelMFA/status/1925459648028545364" target="_blank">Israel Foreign Ministry</a> on Thursday morning as Yaron Lischinsky and Sarah Lynn Milgrim.</li></ul><hr><ul><li>Israeli Ambassador to Washington Yechiel Leiter called them a "beautiful couple" and said Lischinsky had "purchased a ring this week with the intention of proposing to his girlfriend next week in Jerusalem."</li><li>Police identified the suspect as 30-year-old Elias Rodriguez of Chicago, Illinois and said they believe he acted alone.</li></ul><p><strong>The latest: </strong>Attorney General Pam Bondi visited the shooting scene Thursday and told reporters that the suspect "will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law." </p><ul><li>"No parents should have to be called and told that their children were violently murdered leaving a religious event at the Jewish Museum. That should never happen in this world and not in our country," she said. </li><li>Bondi did not offer any updates on the case and would not confirm if the Justice Department would seek the death penalty. </li></ul><p><strong>What they're saying:</strong> President Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke on Thursday, the prime minister's office said in a statement.</p><ul><li>Trump expressed "deep sorrow over the shocking murder in Washington of two Israeli embassy staff members," and Netanyahu thanked Trump for his efforts to combat antisemitism in the U.S., the statement said.</li><li>Trump had previously offered condolences to the victims' families in a Truth Social <a href="https://truthsocial.com/%40realDonaldTrump/posts/114549529250052858" target="_blank">post</a>, saying "These horrible D.C. killings, based obviously on antisemitism, must end, NOW! Hatred and Radicalism have no place in the USA," he said.</li><li><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/trump-wants-netanyahu-end-gaza-war" target="_blank">Netanyahu</a> has <a href="https://x.com/IsraeliPM_heb/status/1925428916811894955" target="_blank">ordered</a> the strengthening of security at Israeli missions around the world and for state representatives in response to the shooting.</li></ul><p><strong>Details: </strong>Smith said police were alerted just after 9pm ET Wednesday about a shooting in the area around the museum in downtown D.C., which is near government buildings including the FBI's Washington Field Office and tourist attractions.</p><ul><li>"Prior to the shooting, the suspect was observed pacing back and forth outside of the museum," Smith said.</li><li>Rodriquez was not previously known to the police, Smith said at the briefing. </li><li>A LinkedIn page shows Rodriquez is an employee of American Osteopathic Information Association (AOIA). The company wrote<a href="https://osteopathic.org/2025/05/22/aoa-aoia-issue-statement-on-israeli-embassy-staff-shooting/" target="_blank"> in a statement</a> that they are "shocked and saddened to learn that an AOIA employee has been arrested as a suspect in this horrific crime." </li></ul><p><strong>Zoom in: </strong>The FBI assisted on the scene and its deputy director <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/02/24/dan-bongino-trump-fbi-deputy-director" target="_blank">Dan Bongino</a> said on X early Thursday that the suspect was being interviewed by the Metropolitan Police Department with the Bureau's Joint Terrorism Task Force team while he, the U.S. Attorney's office and other officials were "reviewing the evidence to determine additional actions."</p><ul><li>He added, "Early indicators are that this is an act of targeted violence."</li><li>D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser said at the briefing, "We will not tolerate any acts of terrorism, and we're going to stand together as a community in the coming days and weeks to send a clear message that we will not tolerate antisemitism."</li></ul><p><strong>Zoom out: </strong>The American Jewish Committee was hosting at the museum the annual Young Diplomats Reception, which "brings together Jewish young professionals ... and the D.C. diplomatic community for an evening dedicated to fostering unity and celebrating Jewish heritage," per a <a href="https://www.ajc.org/events/washington" target="_blank">post</a> by the Jewish advocacy group advertising the event.</p><p><em>Editor's note: This article has been updated with new details throughout.</em></p>

Title: Iran threatens to move nuclear material to secret sites to thwart Israeli strike
Description: <p><a href="https://www.axios.com/world/iran" target="_blank">Iran</a> threatened on Thursday to move its nuclear material to undeclared sites to protect it from a potential Israeli military strike. </p><p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> The threat, made in an <a href="https://x.com/iran_un/status/1925569265987363091?s=46" target="_blank">official letter</a> from Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi to the UN secretary-general and International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) director-general, signal the risk of an unprecedented escalation in the Iranian nuclear crisis. </p><hr><ul><li>The IAEA is currently able to access and monitor Iran's enriched uranium stockpiles, which are stored in declared sites. </li><li>If that material is moved, it will be much harder to know whether Iran is building a nuclear weapon or not. </li></ul><p><strong>Driving the news: </strong>The threat comes after CNN and Axios reported that <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/israel-strike-iran-nuclear-facilities" target="_blank">Israel has been making preparations</a> to swiftly strike Iran's nuclear sites if U.S.-Iran nuclear talks break down in the coming weeks. </p><ul><li>One source told Axios that <a href="https://www.axios.com/world/israel" target="_blank">Israel</a> believes its operational window for a successful strike could close soon.</li></ul><p><strong>What they are saying:</strong> "Under conditions wherein threats made by the Zionist fanatics persist, the Islamic Republic of Iran shall be left with no recourse but to implement special measures for the protection of its nuclear facilities and materials, the relevant particulars of which shall thereafter be communicated to the IAEA," Araghchi wrote. </p><p><strong>Driving the news:</strong> Araghchi and White House envoy Steve Witkoff will hold a fifth round of <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/15/iran-deal-proposal-witkoff-enrichment" target="_blank">nuclear talks</a> in Rome on Friday, with Oman's foreign minister mediating.</p><ul><li>The negotiations have hit a roadblock over the fact that Iran says it will only sign a deal that allows a domestic enrichment capability, and the U.S. has said enrichment is its red line.</li><li>Israeli Strategic Affairs Minister Ron Dermer and the director of Israel's Mossad spy agency David Barnea will meet Witkoff in Rome on Friday on the sidelines of the nuclear talks, two Israeli officials said. </li><li>The officials said Dermer and Barnea are traveling to Rome to coordinate positions with Witkoff and be briefed immediataely after the talks.</li></ul><p><strong>State of play: </strong>The Israeli intelligence community has shifted just in the past few days from believing a <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/16/trump-confirms-us-gave-iran-proposal-for-nuclear-deal" target="_self">nuclear deal</a> was close to thinking talks could soon break down, Israeli sources say. </p><ul><li>Hence the urgency behind Israel's preparations to strike fast if President Trump gives a green light.</li><li>A U.S. official told Axios the Trump administration is concerned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu might make his move even without approval from Trump.</li><li>Trump spoke to Netanyahu on Thursday and they "agreed on the need to ensure that Iran does not obtain nuclear weapons," per the Israeli readout.</li></ul><p><strong>The other side:</strong> Araghchi wrote in his letter that Iran "will take all necessary measures to protect and defend its citizens, interests, and facilities against any terrorist or sabotage actions."</p><ul><li>"Iran strongly warns against any adventurism by the Israeli Zionist regime and will respond decisively to any threats or unlawful actions by this regime. We also believe that if any attack is carried out against the nuclear facilities of the Islamic Republic of Iran by the Israeli regime, the U.S. government will be complicit and bear legal responsibility," the Iranian foreign minister wrote. </li></ul>

Title: Thune threatens Putin with sanctions on Russia
Description: <p>Senate Majority Leader <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/schumer-thune-cra-parliamentarian-nuclear-option" target="_blank">John Thune</a> warned President Vladimir Putin on Thursday that if he does not "make a serious proposal for an immediate ceasefire" with Ukraine, the Senate will pass new sanctions against the Russian government.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>Thune (R-S.D.) is increasing <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/trump-putin-call-european-leaders-zelensky" target="_blank">pressure on Putin</a> by signaling the Senate is willing to act on a bipartisan bill that would authorize new Russian sanctions and tariffs.</p><hr><ul><li>"If Russia is not willing to engage in serious diplomacy, the Senate will work with the Trump administration to consider additional sanctions to force Putin to start negotiating," Thune said Thursday. </li><li>This comes the same week Secretary of State Marco Rubio warned senators in a hearing that if "you start threatening sanctions, the Russians will stop talking."</li><li>"I think it's a next week horizon," Sen. Jeanne Shaheen (D-N.H.) told Axios about the timing of a sanctions bill. "We need to make it very clear to Vladimir Putin that we're going to increase the pressure on Russia to get them to the table to resolve the war in Ukraine.</li></ul><p><strong>Zoom in: </strong>Sens. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn) and Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) have a bill, with 80 cosponsors, that would hit Russia with more economic sanctions if Putin refuses good faith negotiations with Ukraine or launches another attack after any peace deal is reached. </p><ul><li>The bill also would set a 500% tariff on goods imported from countries that buy Russian oil.</li></ul><p><strong>Zoom out: </strong>Thune has previously indicating he was ready to move, but would wait for the signal from the White House.</p><ul><li>Some Republican senators have been urging more immediate action against Putin.</li><li>"I've waited long enough," Sen. Todd Young (R-Ind.) told <a href="https://www.semafor.com/article/05/21/2025/senate-russia-hawks-sick-of-waiting-on-sanctions" target="_blank">Semafor's Burgess Everett</a>, adding, "And it's pretty clear to me that Putin has been jerking us around for months." </li></ul>

Title: Trump's Education Department closure and layoffs blocked by federal judge
Description: <p>A federal judge on Thursday blocked the Trump administration from dismantling the <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/02/05/trump-federal-education-funding-map-schools" target="_blank">Department of Education</a> while a lawsuit challenging the move proceeds.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>The judge's preliminary injunction said that <a href="https://www.axios.com/politics-policy/donald-trump" target="_blank">President Trump</a> and Education Secretary Linda McMahon don't have the power to shutter the agency ‚Äî and that its closure runs contrary to federal laws. </p><hr><ul><li>U.S. District Judge Myong J. Joun of Massachusetts also ordered the administration to reinstate the jobs of terminated Education Department employees. </li><li>"Defendants have not pointed to any case that indicates that the Secretary's effective dismantling of the Department is within her reorganization powers," Joun <a href="https://storage.courtlistener.com/recap/gov.uscourts.mad.282419/gov.uscourts.mad.282419.45.0.pdf" target="_blank">wrote</a>. </li><li>The Trump administration will challenge Joun's ruling "on an emergency basis," Education Department spokesperson Madi Biedermann said in a statement.</li></ul><p><strong>Zoom in: </strong>The judge said the administration didn't provide research to support why certain employees were terminated, why certain offices were reduced or eliminated, or how those changes further the "purported goals of efficiency or effectiveness of the Department." </p><ul><li>He added that students with <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/02/23/trump-attacks-dei-diversity-disability" target="_blank">disabilities</a> would be particularly harmed by reductions at the agency. </li></ul><p><strong>The other side:</strong> "President Trump and the Senate-confirmed Secretary of Education clearly have the authority to make decisions about agency reorganization efforts, not an unelected Judge with a political axe to grind," Biedermann said. </p><ul><li>She said Joun "dramatically overstepped his authority." </li></ul><p><strong>Catch up quick: </strong>Trump in March signed an <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/20/trump-order-education-department-dismantle" target="_blank">executive order</a> to dismantle the Education Department, but shuttering a federal department requires congressional action. </p><ul><li>Also in March, <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/11/education-department-workforce-cuts" target="_blank">nearly 50%</a> of the department's workforce was slashed. </li></ul><p><strong>Go deeper: </strong><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/25/local-schools-federal-funding-superintendents" target="_blank">Education Department cuts threaten to deepen local schools' woes</a></p><p><em>Editor's note: This story has been updated with details throughout and an Education Department statement. </em></p>

Title: 5 key takeaways from highly anticipated MAHA commission report
Description: <p><strong>President Trump's</strong> <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/02/13/trump-maha-commission-rfk-chronic-illness" target="_blank">Make America Healthy Again Commission</a> blamed factors including bad diets, chemical exposure and unnecessary medication for causing childhood chronic illness in a highly anticipated report released Thursday.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>The 68-page document from a panel led by HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. seeks to lay out a unifying theory around what's causing conditions like obesity, autoimmune conditions and behavioral disorders in kids.</p><hr><ul><li>But it was developed in little more than three months and seeks to strike a balance between protecting consumers and promoting economic interests, especially when it comes to <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/19/rfk-roundup-weedkiller-chronic-disease-glyphosate" target="_blank">pesticides</a> and chemicals commonly used in agriculture. </li><li>"This is not, in any way, an attack on the American farmers or industry," NIH director Jay Bhattacharya, a member of the commission, told reporters Thursday. "What this is is a commitment to get excellent answers, excellent science, so that we can enable people to do the right thing." </li></ul><p><strong>The big picture: </strong>As with Kennedy's <a href="https://www.axios.com/2024/11/14/maha-movement-federal-health-agencies" target="_blank">broader health care philosophy,</a> the report blends mainstream ideas with highly controversial elements, including doubts about the current childhood vaccine schedule.</p><p><strong>Here are the key takeaways:</strong></p><p><strong>1. Ultra-processed foods. </strong>The commission, in the first and longest section, acknowledges that popular snacks and beverages save Americans time and money, but cites research that suggests <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/23/food-dye-ban-rfk-pepsi" target="_blank">ultra-processed foods</a> are linked to chronic diseases and says children need more "whole foods." </p><ul><li>"I think everybody wants to prioritize the ultra-processed food crisis and try to reduce our reliance on ultra-processed foods and try to improve the quality of the food," Kennedy said on Thursday. </li></ul><p><strong>2.</strong> <strong>Chemical exposures. </strong>Potential toxins in the environment are a big concern, but the Trump administration is treading lightly. </p><ul><li>Farm groups <a href="https://www.agweb.com/news/policy/politics/farmers-brace-impact-what-maha-report-could-mean-agriculture" target="_blank">worried</a> ahead of the report's release that it would target pesticides like glyphosate, which are widely used in agriculture. </li><li><strong>"</strong>American farmers rely on these products, and actions that further regulate or restrict crop protection tools beyond risk-based and scientific processes set forth by Congress must involve thoughtful consideration of what is necessary for adequate protection, alternatives, and cost of production," the report states.</li></ul><p><strong>3.</strong> <strong>More "gold-standard science." </strong>The report also portrays research on chemical exposure and chronic disease as a necessary competitive advantage for the U.S.<strong> </strong></p><ul><li>Understanding potential links between chemical exposure and chronic illness <strong>"</strong>cannot happen through a European regulatory system that stifles growth," the report says. Rather, it should happen through science done by the federal government and "through unleashing private sector innovation."</li></ul><p><strong>4. Overuse of medicine. </strong>The commission calls out kids' "overmedicalization" ‚Äî and continues to cast <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/fda-limits-covid-boosters" target="_blank">doubt on childhood vaccines</a>. </p><ul><li>It cites a 1,400% increase in antidepressant prescriptions for American adolescents between 1987 and 2014, as well as increased prescribing of stimulants, antibiotics and asthma drugs. </li><li>Long-term research on the impact of commonly used drugs for kids is limited, but there are "contributory human data that raise important questions" about antidepressants, stimulants and other treatments, the report says. </li><li>The commission also questions the current U.S. childhood vaccine protocol and says vaccines would benefit from "more rigorous clinical trial designs." Vaccines are <a href="https://www.immunize.org/wp-content/uploads/catg.d/p2073.pdf" target="_blank">already studied</a> in large trials and subject to ongoing safety surveillance. </li></ul><p><strong>5</strong>. <strong>Corporate influence. </strong>The role of corporate interests features prominently in the report, despite assurances that it's not anti-industry. </p><ul><li>Misaligned incentives in federal regulations and significant scientific funding from food, pharmaceutical, tech and chemical companies contribute to the rise of chronic disease, the report claims. </li></ul><p><strong>Zoom in: </strong>The secretaries of agriculture, education and housing, as well as the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency and other federal officials, sit on the 14<strong>-</strong>member commission. </p><ul><li>White House deputy chief of staff <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/08/stephen-miller-dei-outside-trump-white-house" target="_blank">Stephen Miller</a> is a member, along with Office of Management and Budget Director Russell Vought, who co-authored the Heritage Foundation's <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/01/23/trump-executive-orders-list-project-2025-policies" target="_blank">Project 2025</a>.</li></ul><p><strong>What's next: </strong>The commission now has about 80 days to create a strategy for how the federal government should respond, per Trump's original <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/establishing-the-presidents-make-america-healthy-again-commission/" target="_blank">February order</a>. </p><ul><li>Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said that updated dietary guidelines will likely be released before this fall. </li><li>"What you're going to see is a whole new day on dietary guidelines where federal nutrition advice will be sound. It will be simple, and it will be clear," Rollins said. </li></ul>

Title: Why the bond market is barfing
Description: <p>Around the world, investors are sending a clear-as-glass signal: After years of profligate debt issuance, the world's major <a href="https://www.axios.com/economy" target="_blank">economies</a> are now facing the bill.</p><p><strong>The big picture: </strong>A sell-off in bond markets over recent weeks is signaling that the long-term trajectory for interest rates is higher than it has been in decades. The drop in long-term bond prices means a rise in the interest rates governments must pay to borrow money.</p><hr><ul><li>The anticipated multitrillion-dollar widening of U.S. deficits due to the tax cut and spending legislation that passed the House early Thursday morning is part of the story, as is the <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/19/moodys-credit-rating-us-debt-reason" target="_blank">Moody's downgrade</a> of the U.S. government's credit rating last week.</li><li>But it's really a bigger, global phenomenon ‚Äî suggesting a step-shift in what savers demand to tie up their money in the long term across major advanced economies.</li></ul><p><strong>Driving the news: </strong>The 30-year U.S. Treasury bond yield touched 5.13% at one point Thursday morning, the highest since 2007. On Wednesday, an auction of 20-year bonds showed <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/tepid-demand-us-treasury-auction-shows-investor-jitters-about-tax-bill-deficit-2025-05-21/" target="_blank">surprisingly soft demand</a>.</p><ul><li>In Japan, with the highest ratio on Earth of debt to the size of its economy, long-term bond yields have hit new <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/791cbe4c-2ab5-46e3-9a23-492e86edebcb" target="_blank">all-time highs</a> this week. The nation's 40-year bonds were yielding 3.69% Thursday, up more than a percentage point from early April.</li><li>Long-term rates in the U.K., Canada and Europe have similarly marched upward, if less dramatically.</li></ul><p><strong>State of play: </strong>Moves in shorter-term bonds have been more modest, meaning what has changed is <em>not </em>investors' near-term expectations for the economy, inflation, and monetary policy, but rather the riskiness of locking their money in at low rates.</p><ul><li>In general, a steeper yield curve¬†‚Äî higher long-term rates than short-term rates ‚Äî implies a stronger growth outlook. But there are reasons to think something else is afoot.</li><li>In a volatile world economy ‚Äî one in which globalization marches backward or other negative supply shocks arrive ‚Äî central banks might need to crank rates higher in the coming decades to keep inflation from taking off.</li><li>Moreover, investors worry there will be more government debt issuance in the coming decades than savings to absorb that debt.</li></ul><p><strong>What they're saying: </strong>"This rise has taken place not for virtuous reasons around faster growth but rather because of risks around higher inflation and the need for higher interest rates to compensate for holding long-dated dollar-denominated assets," wrote Joe Brusuelas, chief economist at RSM, in a note.</p><ul><li>"The risks and opportunities around holding such debt are part of the explanation," he added. "A structural change is taking place in the market, forcing a general repricing of risk."</li></ul><div>Data: Federal Reserve; Chart: Axios Visuals</div><p><strong>The long-term bond sell-off</strong> has serious implications for both ordinary American borrowers and the nation's long-term fiscal picture.</p><p><strong>Zoom out: </strong>Because rates on Treasury securities form the bedrock costs for all other forms of borrowing, these higher costs will eventually show up in the form of more expensive mortgages and car loans.</p><ul><li>The good news is that those forms of lending are anchored to shorter-duration rates. Even if you take out a 30-year mortgage, for example, lenders know it will likely be paid off long before that as you move or refinance.</li><li>And shorter-duration rates aren't up much.</li></ul><p><strong>Yes, but: </strong>If bond investors are correct about the long-term trajectory of rates, there will be higher borrowing costs and more lending activity crowded out by the government in the years and decades ahead.</p><p><strong>Zoom in: </strong>If the higher long-term rates hold, it implies meaningfully higher debt service costs for the U.S. government's existing debt pile. That could squeeze the government's ability to pay for other priorities, whether national defense or maintaining the social safety net.</p><p><strong>The bottom line: </strong>"Everybody I have talked to in financial markets, they are staring at the [big, beautiful] bill and they thought it was going to be much more in terms of fiscal restraint," Federal Reserve governor Christopher Waller said Thursday morning on Fox Business.</p><ul><li>"The markets are looking for a little more fiscal discipline," Waller said. "They are concerned."</li></ul>

Title: OpenAI, UAE will build massive Stargate AI center in Abu Dhabi
Description: <p>OpenAI will partner with United Arab Emirates to build Stargate UAE, a massive new Middle East data center that's part of the company's <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/07/openai-democratic-ai-expansion" target="_blank">OpenAI for Countries push</a>, the deal's participants announced Thursday. </p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>The deal is a huge AI bet by the Emirates, which will also secure ChatGPT Plus subscriptions for its entire population, making it the first country to do so.</p><hr><p><strong>Driving the news:</strong> OpenAI and its partners will build a one gigawatt AI computing cluster in Abu Dhabi, with 200 megawatts of that expected to go live next year.</p><ul><li>This new cluster will be part of the larger 5 gigawatt Abu Dhabi data center that Trump and Emirati President Mohammed bin Zayed announced last week.</li><li>Also, for every dollar the UAE invests in Stargate UAE and the broader data center project in Abu Dhabi, UAE will invest an additional dollar in U.S. AI infrastructure as well ‚Äî including <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/01/21/trump-announces-billions-in-private-sector-ai-investment" target="_blank">Stargate</a>.</li><li>A source <a href="https://www.axios.com/newsletters/axios-pro-rata-fd49f847-b35f-49ba-b78d-a50316e9b51a.html" target="_blank">tells Axios' Dan Primack</a> that the new UAE investments, via Emirati-based AI investment vehicle G42, could total $20 billion, with expected outlays in the Gulf and the U.S. at $8 to $10 billion each.  </li></ul><p><strong>The deal is a partnership </strong>with Oracle, Nvidia, Cisco, SoftBank and G42, a Middle East-based AI startup backed by Microsoft and others.</p><ul><li>The U.S. government, which has a say over such deals via its export control authority, also gave its approval to the effort.</li></ul><p><strong>The big picture: </strong>Trump's trip to the Gulf brought a slew of AI infrastructure announcements intended to forge a <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/18/trump-gulf-ai-deals-saudi-uae-security-china-risk" target="_blank">new AI alliance</a> between the U.S. and the region's energy-rich powers.</p><ul><li>The Trump administration sees these deals as opportunities to spread U.S. power and counter Chinese influence. </li><li>Critics fear the flow of American chips and know-how into nations like UAE ‚Äî which has had close ties to China ‚Äî will make it easier for China to gain access to U.S. technology.</li></ul><p><strong>What they're saying:</strong> "By establishing the world's first Stargate outside of the U.S. in the UAE, we're transforming a bold vision into reality," OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said in a statement. "It's a step toward ensuring some of this era's most important breakthroughs ‚Äî safer medicines, personalized learning, and modernized energy ‚Äî can emerge from more places and benefit the world."</p><p><strong>Chris Lehane, </strong>OpenAI vice president of global affairs, told Axios that OpenAI hopes the deal will help "lead as many countries as possible onto the U.S. rails, into the U.S. AI system. This is a real moment in time to do that ‚Äî this is an important first brick in the road. There are two countries in the world that can build this at scale, and the U.S. has a lead."</p><p><strong>What's next:</strong> OpenAI says it wants the UAE deal to be the first of many such arrangements.</p><ul><li>OpenAI chief strategy officer Jason Kwon will kick off a road show across the Asia Pacific region next week, meeting with  governments and potential private-sector partners.</li></ul>

Title: House passes Trump's "big, beautiful bill" after tense GOP talks
Description: <p>The House voted Thursday to pass President Trump's "<a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/economic-growth-big-beautiful-bill-white-house" target="_blank">big, beautiful bill</a>" after weeks of Republican infighting that repeatedly threatened to tank the GOP-only legislation.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>It's a major step toward getting the hulking fiscal package signed into law, though the Senate is likely to make substantial changes that could be difficult for House GOP hardliners to swallow.</p><hr><ul><li>The vote was 215-214. </li><li>The bill would extend the 2017 Trump tax cuts and aims to cut $1.5 trillion in federal spending, including through Medicaid work requirements and the repeal of the Inflation Reduction Act tax credits.</li><li>It took considerable wrangling by House Republican leadership to get to this point, with members of the right-wing House Freedom Caucus <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/mike-johnson-budget-bill-trump-salt-taxes" target="_blank">threatening to oppose it</a> as recently as Wednesday.</li></ul><p><strong>State of play: </strong>The vote came after a marathon congressional session in which some lawmakers stayed up for days.</p><ul><li>The House Rules Committee met early Wednesday morning to markup the bill only ending late Wednesday night.</li><li>House Democrats gummed up the works with several procedural votes, pushing the vote time back to around 6:30 am ET on Thursday.</li></ul>

Title: Are you middle class? It depends who you ask in Congress
Description: <p>The upper bound of "middle class" in America is often pegged at an annual income of between $150,000 and $250,000, but looking at <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/mike-johnson-budget-bill-trump-salt-taxes" target="_blank">legislation</a> being drawn up by Republicans in Congress, it seems to be much, much higher.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>Some of the proposals for the forthcoming budget raise income cutoff levels to as high as $2.5 million per year.</p><hr><p><strong>Driving the news: </strong>The House is considering allowing state and local tax deductions of as much as $40,000 for people making up to $500,000, Axios' <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/mike-johnson-salt-deduction-cap-trump-taxes" target="_blank">Hans Nichols</a> reported this week, a sign that some blue-state Republicans consider $500,000 to be a middle-class income.</p><p><strong>Between the lines: </strong>President Trump considers an annual income of $1 million too modest to justify higher <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/09/trumps-millionaires-tax-rates-mike-johnson" target="_blank">income taxes</a>, per Nichols, but is fine with the idea once household income reaches $2.5 million.</p><ul><li>The current incarnation of the bill also raises the level at which the estate tax starts being levied from $15 million to $30 million.</li></ul><p><strong>Where it stands: </strong>To be in <a href="https://www.bls.gov/news.release/wkyeng.t05.htm" target="_blank">the top 10%</a> of individual earners, a U.S. worker has to earn $2,905 per week, per the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which is $150,000 per year.</p><ul><li>To be in <a href="https://dqydj.com/household-income-percentile-calculator/" target="_blank">the top 10%</a> of households in 2024, you had to earn $235,000.</li><li>The <a href="https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2024/09/16/are-you-in-the-american-middle-class/" target="_blank">middle class</a> tops out at $169,800 for a family of three in 2022 dollars, which is $188,400 in 2025 dollars, according to Pew Research Center.</li></ul><p><strong>How it works:</strong> Some government policies only apply to people making less than a certain amount, on the grounds that the rich are already comfortable enough not to need any extra help from Uncle Sam.</p><ul><li>Looking at where that line gets drawn provides an indicator of where the upper middle class ends and the upper class begins, at least in the eyes of Congress.</li></ul><p><strong>Flashback: </strong>Trump, in his first term, sent out stimulus checks to those making $198,000 per year or less for married households filing jointly. People earning more than that amount were considered rich enough not to need the checks.</p><ul><li>Conversely, the net investment <a href="https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/questions-and-answers-on-the-net-investment-income-tax" target="_blank">income tax</a> ‚Äî a tax on the rich ‚Äî kicks in only once a married couple filing jointly makes over $250,000 per year.</li><li>For President Biden, $400,000 was the key number, the level <a href="https://bidenwhitehouse.archives.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2024/03/11/fact-sheet-the-presidents-budget-cuts-taxes-for-working-families-and-makes-big-corporations-and-the-wealthy-pay-their-fair-share/" target="_blank">below which</a> he said he would never raise taxes, and <a href="https://apnews.com/article/biden-medicare-budget-tax-prescription-drug-costs-99e50b8e956118110dd4a7516318d2cc" target="_blank">above which</a> he wanted a new tax to help pay for Medicare.</li></ul><p><strong>The bottom line: </strong>Now that <a href="https://www.axios.com/local/san-diego/2025/05/16/more-million-dollar-starter-homes-califronia" target="_blank">home values</a> and <a href="https://www.axios.com/2024/08/29/retirement-millionaires-401k-savings" target="_blank">retirement</a> balances regularly make their way into seven-figure territory, we've solidly entered a world of middle-class millionaires.</p>

Title: More Than a Dozen U.S. Officials Sold Stocks Before Trump‚Äôs Tariffs Sent the Market Plunging
Description: 
                <p class="byline">
                by <a class="name" href="https://www.propublica.org/people/robert-faturechi">Robert Faturechi</a>, <a class="name" href="https://www.propublica.org/people/pratheek-rebala">Pratheek Rebala</a> and <a class="name" href="https://www.propublica.org/people/brandon-roberts">Brandon Roberts</a>                </p>
                                             

                                                                    
            
                <p>ProPublica is a nonprofit newsroom that investigates abuses of power. Sign up to receive <a href="https://www.propublica.org/newsletters/the-big-story?source=54G&amp;placement=top-note&amp;region=national">our biggest stories</a> as soon as they‚Äôre published.</p>

            

                

      
  



                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.0">The week before President Donald Trump unveiled bruising new tariffs that sent the <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/business/markets/us-stocks-dow-nasdaq-sp-plummet-trump-tariffs-rcna199476">stock market plummeting</a>, a key official in the agency that shapes his administration‚Äôs trade policy sold off as much as $30,000 of stock. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.1">Two days before that <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2025/04/02/business/trump-tariffs-liberation-day">so-called ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù</a> announcement on April 2, a State Department official sold as much as $50,000 in stock, then bought a similar investment as prices fell.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.2">And just before Trump made another significant tariff announcement, a White House lawyer sold shares in nine companies, records show. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.3">More than a dozen high-ranking executive branch officials and congressional aides have made well-timed trades since Trump took office in January, most of them selling stock before the market plunged amid fears that Trump‚Äôs tariffs would set off a global trade war, according to a ProPublica review of disclosures across the government.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.4">All of the trades came shortly before a significant government announcement or development that could influence stock prices. Some who sold individual stocks or broader market funds used their earnings to buy investments that are generally less risky, such as bonds or treasuries. Others appear to have kept their money in cash. In one case unrelated to tariffs, records show that a congressional aide bought stock in two mining companies shortly before a key Senate committee approved a bill written by his boss that would help the firms.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.5">Using nonpublic information learned at work to trade securities could violate the law. But even if such actions aren‚Äôt influenced by insider knowledge, ethics experts warn that trading stock while the federal government‚Äôs actions move markets can create the appearance of impropriety. The recent trades by government officials, they said, underscore that there should be tighter rules on how, or if, federal employees can trade securities.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.6">‚ÄúThe executive branch is routinely engaged in activities that will move the market,‚Äù said Tyler Gellasch, who, as a congressional aide, helped write the law on insider trading by government officials and now runs a nonprofit focused on transparency and ethics in capital markets. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think members of Congress and executive branch officials should be trading securities. To the extent they have investment holdings, it should be managed by someone else outside their purview. The temptation to put their own personal self-interest ahead of their duties to the country is just too high.‚Äù</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.0">There is no evidence that the trades by government officials identified by ProPublica were informed by nonpublic information. Still, when government officials trade stock at opportune times, Gellasch said, even if it was based on luck and not inside information, it undermines trust in government and the markets</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.1">‚ÄúIt then becomes a thing where our markets look rigged,‚Äù he said.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.2">In response to questions from ProPublica, the officials who made the trades either said they had no insider information that would help them time their decisions or did not respond to questions about the transactions. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.3">Questions about trades based on nonpublic information have swirled around Congress for years and began anew after Trump‚Äôs tariffs announcements led to wild swings in the market. Lawmakers‚Äô trades are automatically posted online and, after multiple congressional stock-trading scandals, are widely scrutinized as soon as they become public. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.4">But less attention is paid to the trades of executive branch employees and congressional aides whose work could give them access to confidential information likely to influence markets once made public.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.5">Last week, <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/pam-bondi-trump-media-stock-tariffs">ProPublica reported</a> that Attorney General Pam Bondi <a href="https://extapps2.oge.gov/201/Presiden.nsf/PAS+Index/102E39A4A731A68785258C8A002C7208/$FILE/Pam-Bondi-05.05.2025-278T.pdf">sold between $1 million and $5 million worth</a> of shares of <a href="https://tmtgcorp.com/">Trump Media</a>, the president‚Äôs social media company, on April 2. After the market closed that day, Trump unveiled his ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù tariffs, sending the market reeling. Bondi‚Äôs <a href="https://extapps2.oge.gov/201/Presiden.nsf/PAS+Index/FC3B6F6F496E257B85258C150032F344/$FILE/Bondi,%20Pam%20%20finalEA.pdf">ethics agreement</a> required her to sell by early May, but why she sold on that date is unclear. She has yet to answer questions about the trades, and the Justice Department did not respond to requests for comment. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.6">Earlier this week, <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/sean-duffy-stock-sales-trump-tariffs">ProPublica reported</a> that Sean Duffy, Trump‚Äôs transportation secretary, <a href="https://extapps2.oge.gov/201/Presiden.nsf/PAS+Index/FED6F4F51D33882F85258C8A002C760E/$FILE/Sean-Duffy-04.23.2025-278T.pdf">sold shares in almost three dozen companies</a> on Feb. 11, two days before Trump announced plans to institute wide-ranging ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs. A Transportation Department spokesperson said Duffy‚Äôs account manager made the trades and that Duffy had no input on the timing.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.7">Using insider government information to buy or sell securities could violate the Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge, or STOCK, Act. But no cases have ever been brought under the law, and some legal experts have doubts it would hold up to scrutiny from the courts, which in recent years have generally narrowed what constitutes illegal insider trading. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.8">Thousands of government employees are required to file disclosure forms if they sell or buy securities worth more than $1,000. In many cases, the records are available only in person in Washington, D.C., or through a records request. The documents do not include exact amounts bought or sold but instead provide a broad range for the totals of each transaction.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.9">ProPublica examined hundreds of records for trades shortly before major tariff announcements or other key government decisions. Trump, of course, repeatedly said on the campaign trail that he intended to institute dramatic tariffs on foreign imports. But during the first weeks of his term, investors were not panic selling, seeming to assume that his campaign promises were bluster. Several tariff announcements by Trump early on shook the markets, but it wasn‚Äôt until he detailed his new tariffs on April 2 that stocks dived. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.10">Among those who sold securities before one of Trump‚Äôs main tariff announcements was Tobias Dorsey. Dorsey, a lawyer in the executive branch since the Obama administration, was named acting general counsel for the White House‚Äôs Office of Administration in January, when Trump was inaugurated. The division provides a range of services, including research and legal counseling across the president‚Äôs staff, including the Office of the United States Trade Representative, which helps craft trade policy. In his LinkedIn bio, Dorsey describes his duties since 2022 as giving ‚Äúexpert advice on a wide range of legal and policy matters to help White House officials achieve their policy goals.‚Äù </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.11">On Feb. 25 and 26, <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950827-tobias-dorsey-03272025-278t/">disclosure records show</a>, Dorsey unloaded shares of an index fund and nine companies, including cleaning products manufacturer Clorox and engineering firm Emerson Electric. The total dollar figure for the sales was between $12,000 and $180,000. (He purchased one stock, defense contractor Palantir, which was selling for a bargain after recently plummeting on news of Pentagon budget cuts.) </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.12">At the time of Dorsey‚Äôs trades, investors were still largely in denial that Trump was going to go through with the massive tariffs he had promised during the campaign. But the next morning, Trump posted on social media that significant tariffs on Mexico and Canada ‚Äúwill, indeed, go into effect, as scheduled‚Äù in several days, and that ‚ÄúChina will likewise be charged an additional 10% Tariff on that date.‚Äù</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.13">The S&amp;P 500, a stock index that tracks a wide swath of the market, fell almost 2% that day alone and ultimately dropped nearly 18% in six weeks.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.14">In an interview, Dorsey said the sale was made by his wife from an account belonging to her. He said she decided to sell around $20,000 worth of shares so they could make tuition payments and that he had no nonpublic information on the impending tariff announcements. The kind of work he does as a career employee, he said, focuses not on public policy, but on how the White House operates, including personnel, workplace technology, contracts and records issues.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.15">‚ÄúI‚Äôm not advising Stephen Miller or Peter Navarro,‚Äù he said, referring to top policy advisers to the president. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm advising the people running the campus. ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt have access to any sensitive political information.‚Äù</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.16">Another well-timed set of transactions was made by Marshall Stallings, the director of intergovernmental affairs and public engagement for Trump‚Äôs Trade Representative. The office helps shape the White House‚Äôs trade policy and negotiates trade deals with foreign governments.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.17">On March 25 and 27, Stallings sold between $2,000 and $30,000 of stock in retail giant Target and mining company Freeport-McMoRan. The sales appear to have been an abrupt U-turn. He had purchased the shares less than a week earlier. Days after Stallings‚Äô sales, Trump unveiled his most dramatic tariffs. Target stock fell 17%. Freeport-McMoRan fell 25%. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.18">Stallings and the Trade Representative‚Äôs office did not respond to multiple requests for comment. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.19">A longtime State Department official, Stephanie Syptak-Ramnath, who until April was ambassador to Peru, also appeared to make a bet against the stock market. On March 24 and 25, she <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950826-stephanie-f-syptak-ramnath-04022025-278t/">sold between $255,000 and $650,000</a> in stocks, and bought between $265,000 and $650,000 in bond and treasury funds (along with $50,000 to $100,000 in stocks). Then, on March 31, two days before Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù announcement, she sold between $15,000 and $50,000 of a broad-based stock fund. When the market started to plummet, she bought back the same dollar range in another stock fund. Syptak-Ramnath said she did not have any information about the administration's decisions beyond what was publicly available. The trades, she said, were ‚Äúundertaken as a result of family obligations‚Äù and in ‚Äúresponse to a changing economy.‚Äù </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.20">A second longtime State Department official, Gautam Rana, who is now ambassador to Slovakia, <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950828-gautam-a-rana-04082025-278t/">sold between $830,000 and $1.7 million</a> worth of stock on March 19, a week before Trump declared new tariffs on cars and two weeks before his ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù announcement. The shares he sold were largely broad-based index funds. Rana declined to comment for this story.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.21">Virginia Canter, a former government ethics lawyer, said executive branch employees who don‚Äôt have nonpublic information and want to trade stock should consult with ethics officials before doing so, thereby allowing an independent third party to assess their actions.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.22">‚ÄúIf you trade and you don‚Äôt seek advice in advance, you kind of do it at your own risk, and if you‚Äôre asked about it, you have to hope there aren‚Äôt factors that make someone question your motivations,‚Äù Canter said. ‚ÄúIf you seek ethics official advice, you have some cover.‚Äù</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.23">Executive branch employees are barred from taking government actions that would narrowly benefit them personally, and some are required to sell stock in companies and industries they have purview over in their jobs. But like members of Congress, they are allowed to trade securities. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.24">Since Trump‚Äôs tariff announcements and walkbacks began causing fluctuations in the market, questions have been raised about whether anyone has profited off advance notice of the moves. After Trump unexpectedly rolled back some of his tariffs in early April, causing stocks to surge, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez warned on social media that ‚Äúany member of Congress who purchased stocks in the last 48 hours should probably disclose that now.‚Äù</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.25">Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene bought between $21,000 and $315,000 of stock the day before and the day of the announcement. In a statement, Greene said a financial adviser controls her investments: ‚ÄúSince my portfolio manager makes my trades for me, I usually find out about them when the media asks.‚Äù</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.26">ProPublica‚Äôs review of disclosures also found trades by congressional aides that took place before the market tumbled. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.27">Michael Platt, a veteran Republican staffer who served in the Commerce Department during Trump‚Äôs first term and now works for the House committee that handles administrative matters for the chamber, restructured his portfolio in <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950851-platt-michael-ptr-2025-04-10/">March</a>. An account under his wife‚Äôs name sold off between $96,000 and $390,000 in mostly American companies, and purchased at least $45,000 in foreign stocks and at least $15,000 in an American and Canadian energy index fund. Some stock forecasters considered international markets a relatively safe haven if Trump went through with his tariffs. Platt did not respond to requests for comment.  </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.28">Stephanie Trifone, a Senate Judiciary Committee aide, sold stock in <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950842-trifone-stephanie-ptr-2025-05-12/">mid-March</a> and bought at least $50,000 in treasuries. A spokesperson for the committee‚Äôs Democratic minority said Trifone had no nonpublic information about the tariffs and her trades were conducted by a financial adviser without her input. Kevin Wheeler, a staffer for the Senate Appropriations Committee, made a similar move. In late February, he and his spouse <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950844-wheeler-kevin-ptr-2025-05-05/">offloaded between $18,000 and $270,000</a> in funds composed almost entirely of stocks and <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950849-wheeler-kevin-ptr-2025-03-28/">bought between $50,000 and $225,000 in bonds</a>. A spokesperson for the Appropriation Committee‚Äôs Republican majority said Wheeler had no nonpublic information about Trump‚Äôs tariff plans and that a financial planner made the trades after advising Wheeler to take a more conservative approach with his portfolio.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.29">Another staffer, Ryan White, chief of staff to Sen. James Risch, R-Idaho, <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950840-white-ryan-ptr-2025-04-19/">bought shares worth between $2,000 and $30,000</a> in two precious metals mining companies <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950840-white-ryan-ptr-2025-04-19/">two days</a> before Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù announcement. He <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950840-white-ryan-ptr-2025-04-19/">continued buying more shares</a> in the companies, Hecla Mining and Coeur Mining, in the following days. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.30">Precious metals can be a safe haven during a bear market turn, but those stocks, like the rest of the market, declined after Trump‚Äôs tariff announcements. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.31">Two days after White‚Äôs last purchase in April of the mining companies‚Äô shares, however, the firms got some good news. A bill White‚Äôs boss introduced to make it easier for mining companies like Hecla and Coeur to operate on public lands was approved by a Senate committee, an important step in passing a bill. (White <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25950845-white-ryan-ptr-2025-05-14/">added to his Hecla shares</a> earlier this month and sold his stake in Coeur.)</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.32">White told ProPublica that ‚Äúall required reporting and ethics rules were followed.‚Äù Any suggestion that the committee passing the bill played a role in his stock purchases ‚Äúis a stretch and patently false,‚Äù he said, adding that the legislation ‚Äúhas not become law and even if it does, would take decades to have any appreciable impact.‚Äù</p>
        
             

                                    
        
                        <p><strong>Update, May 22, 2025:</strong> This story has been updated to include a statement from Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene.</p>

        

    
                                         

Title: Help Us Report on Sexual Assault and Misconduct by the Chicago Police Department
Description: 
                <p class="byline">
                by <a class="name" href="https://invisible.institute/dana-brozost-kelleher">Dana Brozost-Kelleher</a>, <a class="name" href="https://invisible.institute/isabelle-senechal">Isabelle Senechal</a> and <a class="name" href="https://invisible.institute/maria-ines-zamudio">Mar√≠a In√©s Zamudio</a>, <a href="https://invisible.institute/">Invisible Institute</a>                </p>
                                          

        
	<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="1.0">A team of reporters from the nonprofit journalism organizations <a href="https://invisible.institute/introduction">Invisible Institute</a> and <a href="https://www.propublica.org/">ProPublica</a> have reviewed more than 300 sexual assault and misconduct complaints that were filed over the past decade against Chicago police officers.</p>
            
	<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.0">But experts say that‚Äôs likely an undercount.</p>
            
	<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="3.0"><strong>We need your help to understand the scope and scale of this issue.</strong> We want to talk to people who have experienced sexual misconduct or sexual assault by Chicago police. For this investigation, we defined police sexual misconduct as sexual assault, unwanted, inappropriate touching or comments, and sexual harassment by police officers either on or off duty. Researchers and advocates say sexual misconduct is a ‚Äúspectrum of behavior.‚Äù</p>
            
	<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.0">This behavior can include but is not limited to:</p>
            
	<ul>
<li>A Chicago police officer flirting with someone, including by asking for their phone number for reasons not related to a case or by making other inappropriate comments while on duty </li>
<li>A Chicago police officer asking someone for sexual favors in exchange for not ticketing or arresting them</li>
<li>A Chicago police officer sexually assaulting or making unwanted physical contact with someone, including when the officer is off duty</li>
</ul>
</p>
            
	<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="6.0"><a href="https://airtable.com/appx0REbWDR4NzSym/pagFu5m787ZwXmthW/form"><strong>You can share your experience in the form below</strong></a><strong>.</strong> Please also get in touch if you are a current or retired Chicago police officer who has information you can share on this issue.</p>
            
	<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="7.0"><strong>If you prefer to speak with a reporter directly</strong>, you can contact the reporting team by calling or texting 312-488-9552. You can also send a message to reporter Mar√≠a In√©s Zamudio on <a href="https://signal.org/download/">Signal</a>, which is more secure, at mizamudio.95.</p>
            
	<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="8.0">We appreciate you sharing your story and we take your privacy seriously. We are gathering this information for the purposes of our reporting, and we will contact you if we wish to publish any part of your story.</p>
            
	<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="9.0">As journalists, our role is to write about issues. We cannot provide legal advice or other support. However, there are resources available. We know these cases can stem from painful experiences, and support is available if you need it:</p>
            
	<ul>
<li>The <a href="https://rainn.org/resources">National Sexual Assault Hotline</a> is available online or by calling 800-656-4673.</li>
<li>The <a href="https://988lifeline.org">National Suicide and Crisis Lifeline</a> is available online or by calling or texting 988.</li>
<li>The Chicago Rape Crisis Hotline can be reached at 888-293-2080.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ourresilience.org/">Resilience</a><a href="https://www.ourresilience.org/"> in Chicago</a> offers support groups, trauma-informed counseling and advocacy support for survivors.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.caase.org/">Chicago Alliance Against Sexual Exploitation (CAASE)</a> offers legal advice and can make referrals for survivors. </li>
<li><a href="https://the-network.org/">The Network</a> offers support for survivors of domestic violence.</li>
</ul>
</p>
             

				
						
												<p>Andrew Fan, Maheen Khan, Maira Khwaja and Trina Reynolds-Tyler of Invisible Institute contributed reporting, and <a href="https://www.propublica.org/people/ashley-clarke">Ashley Clarke</a> of ProPublica contributed research.</p>

				


      
                               

Title: Chicago Police Dismissed a Recruit‚Äôs Claims That a Colleague Sexually Assaulted Her. Then He was Accused Again and Again.
Description: 
                <p class="byline">
                by <a class="name" href="https://invisible.institute/maria-ines-zamudio">Mar√≠a In√©s Zamudio</a> and <a class="name" href="https://invisible.institute/dana-brozost-kelleher">Dana Brozost-Kelleher</a>, <a href="https://invisible.institute/">Invisible Institute</a>                </p>
                                             

        
                        <p>This article was produced for ProPublica‚Äôs Local Reporting Network in partnership with the <a href="https://invisible.institute/">Invisible Institute</a> and co-published with the <a href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/">Chicago Sun-Times</a> and <a href="https://www.wbez.org/">WBEZ</a>. <a href="https://www.propublica.org/newsletters/dispatches">Sign up for Dispatches</a> to get stories like this one as soon as they are published.</p>

        

    
      
  



                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.0">Alexus Byrd-Maxey had just finished her second month at the Chicago police academy, well on her way to fulfilling her childhood dream.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.1">The South Side native wanted to become a detective so she could bring closure to families who have lost loved ones to homicides by arresting those responsible.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.2">Byrd-Maxey, then 26, was proud of herself for making it this far: completing college classes, applying to the academy multiple times, passing a background check and physical tests. She was delighted to be part of the academy despite the sacrifices it required, including leaving her toddler son most mornings at 5 a.m. and having her mom spend thousands to buy her new uniforms and equipment.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.3">‚ÄúActually sitting in those chairs at the academy was very rewarding,‚Äù she said. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.4">But on March 17, 2023, an encounter with a fellow recruit derailed that dream. On that day, she was leaning over a classmate‚Äôs computer, helping him log on to do their lesson. As another recruit walked behind her, she said she felt his hands on her waist and his body pressed up against her. He was close enough, she told reporters, that she felt ‚Äúhis penis on my butt.‚Äù </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.5">She recalled that she confronted him immediately ‚Äî hoping to hear remorse in his voice. Instead, she said, she saw him smirk. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="2.6">‚ÄúThat‚Äôs when I knew,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not sorry.‚Äù</p>
        
    
                    
    
        <p>
            <strong><a href="https://www.propublica.org/getinvolved/sexual-assault-misconduct-chicago-police-callout">Help Us Report on Sexual Assault and Misconduct by the Chicago Police Department</a></strong>
        </p>

    
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.0">In the days that followed, Byrd-Maxey wrestled with how to report her fellow recruit, a man named Eric Tabb, or whether to let it go. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.1">At the same time, police department investigative records show, Tabb started telling other recruits that Byrd-Maxey had overreacted and that he had only tapped her on the shoulder so he could get to his seat. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.2">The following week, when Byrd-Maxey reported the incident to her class leader, he talked to fellow recruits and they downplayed the encounter. A recruit who allegedly witnessed the incident and was friends with Tabb later told investigators that Byrd-Maxey was ‚Äútrying to victimize herself.‚Äù </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.3">The academy instructor never filed a sexual misconduct complaint. Two and a half weeks later, Byrd-Maxey was fired from the academy for supposedly cursing and using gang language ‚Äî allegations she has denied. Tabb soon became an officer and began patrolling streets.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.4">But he didn‚Äôt last long.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.5">Eight months after Byrd-Maxey was fired, Tabb was arrested for allegedly grabbing a fellow officer‚Äôs genitals repeatedly over her uniform after roll call in their police precinct. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.6">That woman, too, had been in the academy with Byrd-Maxey. Two additional female recruits also have said Tabb assaulted them, and witnesses allege yet another was assaulted but did not report it, meaning five of 17 women in his academy class have given similar accounts, investigative files show. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.7">Tabb now faces multiple felony charges, including aggravated criminal sexual abuse. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="4.8">He has pleaded not guilty, and the criminal case is ongoing. He declined to comment.</p>
        
    
                            
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="6.0">Police department records, including interviews and investigative files obtained by the Invisible Institute and ProPublica, together with court records, highlight how police officials failed to intervene while Tabb was at the academy and head off potential harm to other women. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="6.1">Reporters identified 14 officers who disciplinary records suggest may be repeat offenders, having been accused of sexual assault in the last decade and of at least one other incident of sexual misconduct. Five of those officers faced criminal charges and were convicted, in some cases pleading to a lesser offense that was not a sex crime, and three others have ongoing criminal cases. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="6.2">In reviewing more than 300 sexual misconduct and assault complaints against Chicago police officers, the Invisible Institute and ProPublica found a pattern of the department failing to vigorously investigate accusations of sexual assault by officers, whether those complaints were lodged by fellow cops or members of the public. The claims were often downplayed or ignored, sometimes allowing officers to abuse again and again.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="6.3">A 2017 U.S. Department of Justice investigation into Chicago police found officers frequently minimized the seriousness of sexual misconduct accusations against colleagues and didn‚Äôt employ best-practice investigative techniques. Police, the investigation found, closed cases without conducting full investigations. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="6.4">Police spokesperson Don Terry declined requests for an interview but said in a statement that the department ‚Äútakes all allegations of sexual assault seriously, including allegations against CPD members.‚Äù He said the department has ‚Äúzero tolerance for sexual misconduct and any member in violation will be held accountable.‚Äù </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="6.5">He also said the department works with victim advocacy groups ‚Äúto assist in the appropriate reporting of sexual assault allegations against department members in a way that eliminates barriers to reporting and provides support services to the survivors.‚Äù</p>
        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="8.0">That Tabb allegedly assaulted women while training to become a police officer is particularly troubling. The police academy is where aspiring officers learn the department‚Äôs culture. Recruits get their first lessons in how officers should behave in uniform ‚Äî and out of it. They also have fewer job protections while undergoing their academy training, so they can be easily dismissed if they break the rules. Four other academy recruits have filed sexual misconduct or harassment complaints in the last four years. Records show three of the complaints ended in no discipline for the accused officer and one is still ongoing. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="8.1">‚ÄúI think of it as behavior that you‚Äôre sort of taught in the first few years on the job, starting with your field training officer, what you can get away with,‚Äù said Philip Stinson, a criminal justice professor at Bowling Green State University who has done extensive research on police misconduct and created a national database of officer arrests. ‚ÄúThey learn that it‚Äôs accepted behavior within that culture, within that squad, or that shift, quite often. And I do think that it‚Äôs behaviors that escalate.‚Äù</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="8.2">In June 2023, a little over two months after Byrd-Maxey was kicked out of the academy, the department implemented its first sexual misconduct policy, one it had been working on before she began her training.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            Former Chicago police Officer Eric Tabb walks out of a Chicago courthouse after a hearing. He faces multiple charges, including aggravated criminal sexual abuse.
    
            (Jamie Kelter Davis for ProPublica)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
A Pattern of Missed Opportunities
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="10.0">The Chicago Police Department has a long history of failing to identify and deal with patterns of troubling behavior within its ranks. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="10.1">Officers who stole from suspects were able to do so repeatedly before getting caught. Detectives who coerced confessions, sending innocent people to prison and costing the city tens of millions of dollars in legal settlements, did so without ever being disciplined. And some cops who abused and tortured Chicagoans did so for years before they were stopped.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="10.2">This failure of the department to police its own officers has also had devastating consequences for people who have accused officers of sexual assault or harassment. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="10.3">In 2019, then-Superintendent Eddie Johnson praised the department‚Äôs internal investigation of 13-year police veteran Officer Corey Deanes, who had been accused of sexual misconduct by four women. He called it a ‚Äútestament to our ability to police ourselves.‚Äù</p>
        
    
                            
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.0">But what Johnson didn‚Äôt mention was that the department allowed Deanes to police the city‚Äôs streets for nearly a year despite two allegations of sexual misconduct. It took the city‚Äôs civilian police oversight agency to identify his behavior and stop him. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.1">Deanes was suspended for seven days in 2011 for sexually harassing a woman during a traffic stop. He insisted on getting her phone number, then called or texted nearly 30 times. He told investigators he had no official reason to pull the woman over but did so because he wanted to talk to her. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.2">Six years later, in August 2017, he again was accused of abusing his position while pulling over a 23-year-old woman during a traffic stop. Deanes, according to internal affairs records, made inappropriate comments to her and threatened to write the woman a ticket if she did not give him her phone number. Then Deanes allegedly hugged her and, though she resisted, touched her buttocks before leaving without giving her a ticket. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.3">The woman reported the incident to the Chicago police and to the Independent Police Review Authority, the civilian oversight agency at the time. Police records and a lawsuit brought by the woman indicate it took police investigators more than a year to interview her, and the department lost an opportunity to get Deanes off the streets. The city settled the woman‚Äôs lawsuit for $100,000.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.4">In July 2018, another Chicago woman reported Deanes. She had called 911 for help after arriving home late at night and finding a stranger on her porch. Deanes, who responded to the call, allegedly asked her personal questions, commented on her body and touched her inappropriately, according to internal affairs records.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.5">‚ÄúI felt so violated,‚Äù the woman, who asked to remain anonymous for fear of retaliation, told Invisible Institute and ProPublica. ‚ÄúI called you for help and I got harassed. That is not OK.‚Äù </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.6">The woman reported the incident to the Civilian Office of Police Accountability, the latest iteration of the review board. Launched in 2017 as part of a wider series of reforms, COPA and its new leaders hoped to bring an additional focus to investigating claims of domestic violence and sexual assault committed by officers.</p>
