<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.7">Yet another woman filed a complaint against Deanes two weeks after the incident with the 911 call. This time, COPA identified a pattern. Andrea Kersten, then COPA‚Äôs head of investigations, notified the police department‚Äôs Bureau of Internal Affairs about the three incidents and pushed for a criminal investigation. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="12.8">Deanes was arrested in May 2019 and charged with two misdemeanor counts of battery, one felony count of aggravated battery, and three felony counts of official misconduct for the three separate incidents. He pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of misdemeanor battery in 2020 and received two years probation. He was stripped of his Illinois state certification, preventing him from working as a cop.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            A letter from the Chicago Police Department‚Äôs Bureau of Internal Affairs outlining the allegations against then-Officer Corey Deanes and suggesting his case be closed after he pleaded guilty to misdemeanor battery in 2020.
    
            (Obtained by Invisible Institute. ProPublica redacted identifying information for the sending, receiving and approving officers; other redactions original.)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="14.0">The woman who encountered Deanes after the 911 call said she‚Äôs disappointed that it took so long for the department to take action. ‚ÄúPolice will have each other‚Äôs backs no matter what heinous things they do,‚Äù she said. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="14.1">Deanes declined to comment for this story. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="14.2">COPA has taken steps to improve its handling of sexual misconduct cases to identify officers who repeatedly engage in misconduct. Under Kersten‚Äôs leadership, the agency created a Special Victims Squad of trained investigators in 2019 to pursue these cases, including those with limited evidence beyond the accuser‚Äôs word. COPA also entered into an agreement that allowed other agencies to conduct joint interviews with victims to enhance collaboration and to reduce the risk of retraumatizing victims by limiting retellings of their assault. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="14.3">Kersten stepped down as the head of COPA in February after facing a possible no-confidence vote from an oversight board and ongoing lawsuits against <a href="https://dockets.justia.com/docket/illinois/ilndce/1:2024cv07376/463117">Kersten and COPA.</a> A lawsuit filed by the Fraternal Order of Police, the union representing Chicago police officers, alleged that COPA and Kersten have exhibited an anti-police bias that unfairly affects investigations and how officers are disciplined. A federal judge dismissed the suit in April.</p>
        
    
                            
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="16.0">Kersten declined to comment for this story, but in her resignation letter she disputed the claims against her. COPA‚Äôs interim chief administrator said the agency remains committed to pursuing investigations of sexual misconduct. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="16.1">‚ÄúWe are working on growing our SVS section to a fuller unit with more staff who will receive specialized training to handle these investigations,‚Äù the administrator, LaKenya White, said in a statement. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="16.2">While COPA participated in the investigation into Byrd-Maxey‚Äôs claims, internal affairs led the criminal investigation into the matter.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            The Chicago Police Education and Training Academy
    
            (Jamie Kelter Davis for ProPublica)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
‚ÄúI‚Äôm Not Going Nowhere.‚Äù
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="18.0">Last fall, Alexus Byrd-Maxey had come to accept what she called God‚Äôs will ‚Äî that she would not become a Chicago police officer. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="18.1">Since being fired from the academy, she had struggled with depression and anxiety as she tried to rebuild her life. She went back to work as a waitress at a North Side restaurant. Yet every time she saw her police uniforms hanging in her closet, she grieved a life she would never have. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="18.2">‚ÄúI feel like I was stripped away from it,‚Äù she said. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="18.3">She thought she was doing the right thing in reporting Tabb, whether he was disciplined or not.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            Byrd-Maxey‚Äôs police equipment and uniform from her time as a police recruit
    
            (Jamie Kelter Davis for ProPublica)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="20.0">It wasn‚Äôt long after Byrd-Maxey tried to alert the academy about Tabb that a second incident occurred. At the end of August 2023, Tabb attended a birthday celebration at a Wrigleyville bar with other recruits. He joined a female recruit on the dance floor and, according to investigative reports and court records, touched her breast, buttock and crotch over her clothes and also grabbed her face and tried to kiss her. He was so aggressive, a witness told investigators, that a mutual friend had to intervene to get him away from the recruit. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="20.1">A few days later, according to investigative files and court records, Tabb attended a ‚Äústar party,‚Äù an unofficial celebration for graduating recruits receiving their badge number. Another recruit told investigators he saw Tabb grabbing a third female recruit‚Äôs genitals over her clothes. The recruit‚Äôs boyfriend confronted Tabb, according to a witness. That same night, Tabb touched a fourth recruit‚Äôs buttocks, according to interviews with police investigators and court records. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="20.2">In the immediate aftermath, the three women said nothing, and soon Tabb was officially on the force.</p>
        
    
                            
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="22.0">After about three months, a fifth female officer accused Tabb of touching her crotch over her uniform several times when she stood up after roll call to adjust her duty belt.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="22.1">The woman went to her supervisor despite her fears. ‚ÄúI was afraid that any type of confrontation or anything would not work out for me,‚Äù she later told investigators. ‚ÄúI felt powerless,‚Äù the woman said, crying. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="22.2">She said Tabb grabbed her crotch a second time.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="22.3">‚ÄúHe sat back in his chair and he had a slight smile on his face with his hand up to his chin,‚Äù she said in a recorded interview with investigators. ‚ÄúIt looked to me like, I don‚Äôt know, like he was proud of what he did.‚Äù</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="22.4">During the investigation into that incident, officials uncovered the allegations against Tabb that involved his off-duty behavior toward recruits. Two of the three recruits stepped forward to report Tabb‚Äôs behavior because they said they wanted to support the final alleged victim.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            An internal affairs report outlining the investigation into Tabb‚Äôs first alleged assault.
    
            (Obtained by Invisible Institute. ProPublica redacted identifying information for the sending and receiving officers and those who reported and received reports of the incident; other redactions original.)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="24.0">Even though Byrd-Maxey had been the first to report his behavior, no one contacted her for 15 months about the criminal case against Tabb. When she learned about it, she decided to attend his next court hearing. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="24.1">On a Tuesday morning in March, Byrd-Maxey entered the busy Cook County criminal courthouse with her mom, Jauntaunne Byrd-Horne. They walked past the black Doric columns and the tall golden lamps on their way to a courtroom, where a hearing was scheduled in Tabb‚Äôs case. For the first time in nearly two years, she was going to see him.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="24.2">Her mom made herself a T-shirt to ensure her daughter‚Äôs pain was acknowledged. In bold white letters against a black background, the front of the shirt read: ‚ÄúWhat about Tabb‚Äôs first police academy victim 03/17/2023?‚Äù</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="24.3">Byrd-Maxey and her mother sat in the courtroom‚Äôs first row. A few minutes later, Tabb arrived with his parents and sat behind them. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="24.4">At issue was a request from prosecutors asking to have the additional allegations related to off-duty incidents considered as evidence of a pattern of behavior: similar victims, similar assaults. Dan Herbert, Tabb‚Äôs defense attorney, said his client was innocent. He tried to blame Byrd-Maxey for the claims involving all the off-duty recruits, implying she had a grudge against Tabb.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            Byrd-Horne, left, and Byrd-Maxey stand outside the George N. Leighton Criminal Courthouse after a March hearing in the case of former police Officer Eric Tabb.
    
            (Jamie Kelter Davis for ProPublica)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="26.0">Records show that before she was fired, Byrd-Maxey tried to report Tabb multiple times. She talked to her class leader ‚Äî a fellow recruit who is put in a leadership position ‚Äî on the Monday following the Friday incident. Records show the class leader discussed the incident with superiors and placed more emphasis on Tabb‚Äôs version, which was supported by other recruits. No one filed an official complaint. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="26.1">Almost three weeks later, conflict erupted in class. Byrd-Maxey claimed Tabb verbally attacked her, and Tabb accused her of doing the same, records show. After class, Byrd-Maxey said, she went to her instructor to tell him about the incident in the computer lab. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="26.2">Byrd-Maxey was fired the next day, accused of saying ‚Äúshut your bitch ass up‚Äù in class and using gang-related language. Though their names were redacted, investigative files show seven recruits, including Tabb, filed complaints against Byrd-Maxey for engaging in this behavior. She denies the allegations.</p>
        
    
                            
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="28.0">The next day, Byrd-Maxey returned to the police academy to file the sexual misconduct complaint herself. She also accused two instructors of wrongful termination. During that investigation, several recruits sided with Tabb, including three who told investigators they were in the computer lab at the time.</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="28.1">By the time internal affairs cleared Tabb of Byrd-Maxey‚Äôs complaint on Sept. 20, 2023, he had allegedly assaulted three other women from his academy class. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="28.2">During the court hearing, Tabb‚Äôs attorney attacked the credibility of those officers for not reporting the alleged abuse the moment it happened. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="28.3">‚ÄúThey‚Äôre police officers. They have a duty to report misconduct,‚Äù Herbert said. ‚ÄúAnd they‚Äôre probationary police officers, which as the court well knows, they can be fired for any reason, unless it‚Äôs an illegal reason. They can be fired for not reporting misconduct. I think that‚Äôs what happened in this case.‚Äù</p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="28.4">After the hearing, Byrd-Maxey spotted Tabb in the courthouse lobby. She locked eyes with him as their paths crossed.</p>
        
    
                            
    
                    
<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="30.0">‚ÄúI‚Äôm here. I‚Äôm not going nowhere,‚Äù she said afterward. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="30.1">Byrd-Maxey and her mother embraced outside the courthouse, an acknowledgment of the toll reporting Tabb had taken on them both. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="30.2">Yet she doesn‚Äôt regret it. </p>

<p data-pp-blocktype="copy" data-pp-id="30.3">‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt change anything, even though it cost me mentally and financially,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt change it because, at the end of the day, I had the right motive to be heard and to avoid this from happening again.‚Äù</p>


</p>
        
    
                    

    Methodology
<p>Invisible Institute reporters spent over a year identifying allegations of sexual assault and sexual misconduct by Chicago police officers, then created a database from those allegations. We reviewed hundreds of complaints obtained through public records requests and a lawsuit. </p>
<p>Reporters obtained investigative files from the Chicago Police Department‚Äôs Bureau of Internal Affairs, the Civilian Office of Police Accountability, and its predecessor agency, the Independent Police Review Authority. Reporters read the original investigative files, examined evidence and reviewed lawsuits, court records and media accounts. </p>
<p>The Invisible Institute and ProPublica compiled a dataset of more than 300 complaints after excluding dozens of cases where body camera footage contradicted the allegation, where non-police witnesses affirmed the police account, or where a secondhand allegation was not corroborated.</p>
<p>This investigation would not be possible without previous litigation that pushed for disciplinary records to be open to the public despite resistance from the city. Those lawsuits include <a href="https://invisible.institute/bond-v-utreras-intervention">Bond v. Utreras</a>, <a href="https://www.chicagotribune.com/2020/07/17/commentary-a-proposed-settlement-would-broadside-police-accountability-that-should-never-happen/">Green v. Chicago Police Department</a> and <a href="https://www.cjr.org/united_states_project/jamie_kalven_diane_bond_chicago_police_misconduct_foia.php">Kalven v. Chicago</a>, which was brought by Jamie Kalven, founder of the Invisible Institute, and led to the publication of police misconduct complaints on the <a href="http://cpdp.co">Civic Police Data Project</a> site.</p>



        
             

                                    
        
                        <p>This story was published with the support of a grant from Columbia University‚Äôs Ira A. Lipman Center for Journalism and Civil and Human Rights, in conjunction with Arnold Ventures.</p>

        

    


                                    
        
                        <p>Andrew Fan, Maheen Khan and Isabelle Senechal of the Invisible Institute contributed reporting and data analysis. <a href="https://www.propublica.org/people/mariam-elba">Mariam Elba</a> of ProPublica contributed research and <a href="https://www.propublica.org/people/agnel-philip">Agnel Philip</a> of ProPublica contributed data analysis.</p>

        

    
                                         

Title: Unlearning or Obfuscating? Jogging the Memory of Unlearned LLMs via Benign Relearning
Description: Machine unlearning is a promising approach to mitigate undesirable memorization of training data in ML models. In this post, we will discuss our work (which appeared at ICLR 2025) demonstrating that existing approaches for unlearning in LLMs are surprisingly susceptible to a simple set of benign relearning attacks: With access to only a small and potentially loosely related set of data, we find that we can ‚Äújog‚Äù the memory of unlearned models to reverse the effects of unlearning.¬† For example, we show that relearning on public medical articles can lead an unlearned LLM to output harmful knowledge about bioweapons, and relearning general wiki information about the book series Harry Potter can force the model to output verbatim memorized text. We formalize this unlearning-relearning pipeline, explore the attack across three popular unlearning benchmarks, and discuss future directions and guidelines that result from our study. Our work offers a cautionary tale to the unlearning community‚Äîshowing that current approximate unlearning methods simply suppress the model outputs and fail to robustly forget target knowledge in the LLMs. What is Machine Unlearning and how can it be attacked? The initial concept of machine unlearning was motivated by GDPR regulations around the &#8220;right to be forgotten&#8221;, [&#8230;]

Title: Spring Boot 3.5 Delivers Improved Configuration, Containers, and SSL, Shortens Free Support
Description: <img src="https://res.infoq.com/news/2025/05/spring-boot-3-5/en/headerimage/generatedHeaderImage-1747893414525.jpg"/><p>Broadcom launched Spring Boot 3.5, improving configuration, containers, and SSL. Spring Framework 7.0 and Spring Boot 4.0 start a new generation in November 2025.</p> <i>By Karsten Silz</i>

Title: ÁâπÊúóÊôÆÊâìÂéãÂìà‰ΩõÔºå‰∏≠ÂõΩ‰∫∫ÂÜçÊ¨°ÂØπÁæéÂõΩÁ•õÈ≠Ö
Description: Â∞ΩÁÆ°ËÆ∏Â§öË±°ÂæÅÁæéÂõΩÁöÑ‰∫ãÁâ©ÂØπ‰∏≠ÂõΩÊ∞ë‰ºóÁöÑÂê∏ÂºïÂäõÊó•ÁõäÂáèÂº±ÔºåÂìà‰ΩõÁ≠âÁ≤æËã±Â§ßÂ≠¶‰ªçÊòØ‰∫∫‰ª¨ÂêëÂæÄÊàñÂ¥áÊãúÁöÑÂØπË±°„ÄÇÁâπÊúóÊôÆÊîøÂ∫úÈíàÂØπÂìà‰ΩõÁöÑ‰∏æÊé™ÂèØËÉΩÊñ≠ÁªùËøôÁßçÂêëÂæÄÔºåËøõËÄåÈáçÂ°ë‰∏§ÂõΩÁöÑÊï¥‰ΩìÂÖ≥Á≥ª„ÄÇ<p><img src='https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/05/23/multimedia/23int-china-harvard-01-twjk/23int-china-harvard-01-twjk-articleLarge.jpg' alt='È©¨Ëê®ËØ∏Â°ûÂ∑ûÂùéÂ∏ÉÈáåÂ•áÁöÑÂìà‰ΩõÂ§ßÂ≠¶Ê†°Âõ≠ÔºåÊëÑ‰∫é4Êúà„ÄÇÂÉèÂìà‰ΩõËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÁæéÂõΩÂ§ßÂ≠¶‰æùÁÑ∂ÂØπ‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ≠¶ÁîüÂÖ∑ÊúâÂê∏ÂºïÂäõ„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰∫ÜËøΩÊ±Ç‰∏ñÁïå‰∏ÄÊµÅÁöÑÊïôËÇ≤Ôºå‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ≠¶ÁîüÊÑøÊÑèÂøΩËßÜÂÖ∂‰ªñÈ°æËôë„ÄÇ Sophie Park for The New York Times'/></p>                    <p style='text-align: right; color: gray; font-size: 11px!important; line-height: 10px;'>Sophie Park for The New York Times</p>                    <p style='text-align: left; color: gray; font-size: 11px!important; line-height: 10px;'>È©¨Ëê®ËØ∏Â°ûÂ∑ûÂùéÂ∏ÉÈáåÂ•áÁöÑÂìà‰ΩõÂ§ßÂ≠¶Ê†°Âõ≠ÔºåÊëÑ‰∫é4Êúà„ÄÇÂÉèÂìà‰ΩõËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÁæéÂõΩÂ§ßÂ≠¶‰æùÁÑ∂ÂØπ‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ≠¶ÁîüÂÖ∑ÊúâÂê∏ÂºïÂäõ„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰∫ÜËøΩÊ±Ç‰∏ñÁïå‰∏ÄÊµÅÁöÑÊïôËÇ≤Ôºå‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ≠¶ÁîüÊÑøÊÑèÂøΩËßÜÂÖ∂‰ªñÈ°æËôë„ÄÇ</p>                    

Title: ÁâπÊúóÊôÆÂØπÂ∑¥ÊãøÈ©¨ËøêÊ≤≥ÁöÑÂç±Èô©Áó¥Ëø∑

<p style="text-align: left;">SKUÁ≤æÈÄâÂåñÔºåÂπ∂Âú®5000-8000‰∏™SKU‰∏≠ËÆæÁ´ã1000‰∏™ÈïøÊúüÂºïÊµÅÂìÅ„ÄÇÂ¢ûËÆæÈ£üÂ†Ç„ÄÅÂÑøÁ´•‰πêÂõ≠Á≠â‰ΩìÈ™åÂå∫Ôºå‰ª•ÊâìÈÄ†‚ÄúÁ§æÂå∫ÁîüÊ¥ª‰∏≠ÂøÉ‚Äù„ÄÇ</p>

<p style="text-align: left;">Â§ßÊ∂¶ÂèëSuperÈááÁî®Ê®°ÂùóÂåñËÆæËÆ°ÁêÜÂøµÔºåÊ†πÊçÆÂë®ËæπÂ±ÖÊ∞ë‰∫∫Êï∞ËÆæËÆ°ÂçñÂú∫ÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞è„ÄÅSKUÊï∞ÁõÆ‰πÉËá≥ËøõÂ∫óÂä®Á∫øÔºåËÉΩÂø´ÈÄüÈÄÇÈÖç‰∏çÂêåÁ±ªÂûãÂïÜÂúàÂºÄÂ∫ó„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Ê≠§Â§ñÊØèÂÆ∂Èó®Â∫óÊã•Êúâ500-1000‰∏™SKUÁöÑÁ©∫Èó¥ÔºåÂèØÊ†πÊçÆÂΩìÂú∞ÈúÄÊ±Ç„ÄÅÂïÜÂúàÁâπÊÄßÈíàÂØπÊÄßÈÄâÂìÅ„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Áõ∏ÊØî‰∫éÁõòË∏ûÂú®Âçé‰∏ú‰∫å„ÄÅ‰∏âÁ∫øÂüéÂ∏ÇÁöÑM‰ºöÂëòÂ∫óÔºåÂ§ßÊ∂¶ÂèëSuperÈó®Â∫óÂàÜÊï£Âú®ÂÖ®ÂõΩ11‰∏™ÁúÅÂ∏ÇÔºåÂçé‰∏úÂå∫Èó®Â∫óÂç†ÊØîËøë‰∏âÂàÜ‰πã‰∏Ä„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Âú®È´òÈë´Èõ∂ÂîÆÁúãÊù•ÔºåÂ§ßÊ∂¶ÂèëSuperÂ∞ÜÊàê‰∏∫Êú™Êù•Êâ©Âº†ÂèäÂõûÂΩíÈ´òÁ∫øÂüéÂ∏ÇÁöÑ‰∏ªË¶ÅÂä®Âäõ„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">‰∏çËøá‰∏ä‰∏ÄË¥¢Âπ¥ÔºåÂ§ßÊ∂¶ÂèëSuperÊñ∞ÂºÄ4ÂÆ∂„ÄÅÂÖ≥Â∫ó1ÂÆ∂ÔºåÈó®Â∫óÊÄªÊï∞‰ªÖ33ÂÆ∂ÔºåÊú™ÂèäÂ§ßÊ∂¶ÂèëÁöÑÂçÅÂàÜ‰πã‰∏Ä„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;"><strong>Áõ∏ÊØî‰πã‰∏ãÔºåM‰ºöÂëòÂ∫óÊãìÂº†ÊÉÖÂÜµ‰ºº‰πéÊõ¥‰∏∫ÊòéÊúó„ÄÇ</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: left;">‰Ωú‰∏∫Â∞ëÊúâÁöÑÊú¨Âúü‰ªìÂÇ®‰ºöÂëòÂ∫óÁé©ÂÆ∂ÔºåM‰ºöÂëòÂ∫ó‰∏éÂ±±ÂßÜ‰ºöÂëò‰ª∑Â§ÑÂú®Âêå‰∏ÄÊ∞¥Âπ≥Ôºå‰ª∑Ê†º‰∏äÂπ∂Êó†Á´û‰∫â‰ºòÂäø„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Áé∞ÊúâÁöÑ‰ºöÂëòÂ∫óÂá†‰πéÂùáÁî±ÂéüÂ§ßÂçñÂú∫ÊîπÈÄ†ËÄåÊù•ÔºåËá™ÊúâÁâ©‰∏ö‰øùÈöú‰∫ÜÂÖ∂Âú®ÂºÄÂ∫óÈÄüÂ∫¶ÂèäÊàêÊú¨ÊéßÂà∂‰∏äÔºåËæÉÊØîÂ±±ÂßÜÈ¢ÜÂÖà‰∏ÄÊà™„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">È´òÈë´Èõ∂ÂîÆM‰ºöÂëòÂïÜÂ∫ó‰∫ã‰∏öÈÉ®ÊÄªÁªèÁêÜË¢ÅÂΩ¨Ë°®Á§∫ÔºåM‰ºöÂëòÂïÜÂ∫óÊ≤°Êúâ‚ÄúÂåÖË¢±‚ÄùÔºåÂïÜÂìÅÊØõÂà©‰∏éËøêËê•ÊàêÊú¨Â∑≤ÁªèÊâìÂπ≥„ÄÇ</p>

Title: "Criminal act": Kim Jong-un denounces failed North Korean warship launch
Description: <p><a href="https://www.axios.com/world/north-korea" target="_blank">North Korean</a> leader Kim Jong-un responded with fury after watching a "serious accident" occur during the launch of a new warship on Thursday that he described as a "criminal act," the state-run KCNA reported.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>It's highly unusual for Kim to criticize his defense forces or for state media to report on an error ‚Äî though KCNA did not disclose whether there were any casualties as it reported that parts of the 5,000-ton destroyer were crushed in the incident.</p><hr><img src="https://images.axios.com/MS4r-X0OnksK5aNwN5k2uYRj8Rs=/2025/05/23/1747962848159.jpg"> <div>In a photo taken in Seoul on Thursday, people sit near a television featuring news footage with a satellite still image courtesy of Maxar Technologies showing a general view of a new North Korean warship at the harbor ahead of its launch in Chongjin, North Korea. Photo: Anthony Wallace/AFP via Getty Images</div><p><strong>Details: </strong>KCNA said the incident occurred due to "inexperienced command and operational carelessness in the course of the launch."</p><ul><li>Kim made a "stern assessment, saying that it was a serious accident and criminal act caused by sheer carelessness, irresponsibility and unscientific empiricism which should never occur and could not be tolerated," per KCNA.</li><li>He ordered that the ship be restored following the incident at the shipyard in the northeastern port city of Chongjin "that lowered the dignity and self-respect of our state," according to KCNA</li><li>North Korean officials have launched "a full-scale investigation" into the matter, KCNA said on Friday morning local time.</li><li>"It is necessary to make clear the cause of the accident," KCNA said.</li></ul><p><strong>Between the lines: </strong>KCNA reported that the "extent of damage to the warship is not serious," but the U.K.-based Open Source Centre <a href="https://x.com/osc_london/status/1925465203187085693" target="_blank">noted</a> on X that satellite images of the frigate on its side beside the dock show it was "significantly damaged."</p><ul><li>The high resolution imagery "shows the ship lies partially submerged on its side, tarpaulins draped over the wreckage in a visible attempt to contain the disaster," <a href="https://x.com/osc_london/status/1925465206706040959" target="_blank">said</a> the nonprofit that works in open source intelligence and analytics.</li><li>"This was the second new destroyer built by the Pyongyang regime in the last year, with another launched in April in Nampo."</li></ul><p><strong>Go deeper: </strong><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/27/north-korea-talks-kim-jong-un-trump" target="_blank">Trump admin game-planning for potential North Korea talks</a></p>

Title: Harvard ban is warning to other universities, Noem says
Description: <p>Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem warned universities on Thursday to "get your act together" after <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/22/harvard-trump-international-students-dhs" target="_blank">halting Harvard's program</a> to enroll international students.</p><p><strong>The big picture: </strong>The Trump administration has <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/17/universities-trump-harvard-columbia" target="_blank">targeted</a> educational institutions, <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/16/harvard-columbia-demands-trump-vision-universities-influence" target="_self">pressuring universities</a> to meet its demands or risk losing funding and tax-exempt status.</p><hr><p><strong>State of play:</strong> In the latest escalation,<strong> </strong>Noem on Thursday ordered the Department of Homeland Security to terminate Harvard's ability to enroll international students, and said those currently enrolled have to transfer or lose their legal status.</p><ul><li>She <a href="https://www.dhs.gov/news/2025/05/22/harvard-university-loses-student-and-exchange-visitor-program-certification-pro" target="_blank">accused</a> the university of "fostering violence, antisemitism and coordinating with the Chinese Communist Party on its campus."</li><li>Harvard called the move unlawful and said it's "fully committed to maintaining Harvard's ability to host international students and scholars."</li></ul><p><strong>What she's saying: </strong>"This should be a warning to every other university to get your act together," Noem said on <a href="https://www.foxnews.com/video/6373250639112" target="_blank">Fox News</a> on Thursday.</p><ul><li>"Get your act together because we are coming to make sure that these programs ... are facilitating an environment where students can learn, where they're safe and that they're not discriminated against based on their race or their religion," she continued.</li><li>"Anti-semitism will not be stood for and any participation with a country or an entity or a terrorist group that hates America and perpetuates this kind of violence, we will stop it, and we will not allow that to happen."</li></ul><p><strong>Zoom out: </strong>The administration's recent <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/14/harvard-reject-trump-funding-deal-billions" target="_self">demands of Harvard</a> and other elite institutions depict the <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/16/harvard-columbia-demands-trump-vision-universities-influence" target="_blank">government's playbook</a> to influence and reorient the priorities of universities through federal funds.</p><ul><li>The administration's stated objective is weeding out antisemitism, but it's also pushing President <a href="https://www.axios.com/politics-policy/donald-trump" target="_self">Trump</a>'s vision of eliminating perceived liberal slants, sharpening discipline measures and reconstructing the makeup of student and faculty bodies.</li></ul><p><strong>Case in point: </strong>Harvard last month became the first university to reject <a href="https://www.harvard.edu/research-funding/wp-content/uploads/sites/16/2025/04/Letter-Sent-to-Harvard-2025-04-11.pdf" target="_blank">the administration's demands</a> tied to its federal funding. It was met with $2 billion in grants being frozen and the IRS taking steps <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2025/04/16/politics/irs-harvard-tax-exempt-status/" target="_blank">to revoke</a> the university's tax-exempt status.</p><ul><li>Columbia, meanwhile, regained <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/07/trump-columbia-antisemitism-protests-federal-money" target="_self">$400 million</a> in federal grants and contracts the administration had pulled after the university agreed <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/21/columbia-trump-federal-funding-protests" target="_self">to meet</a> some demands.</li><li>Funding for Cornell, Northwestern, Brown and Princeton has also been facing potential cuts. </li><li>In the face of <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/03/21/colleges-research-funding-trump-threat" target="_self">threats to higher education institutions</a>, faculty members at several Big Ten universities <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/24/big-ten-joint-pact-trump-administration-universities" target="_blank">asked their administrations</a> to consider a joint defense pact.</li></ul><p><strong>Between the lines: </strong>"This is a blueprint for fealty to the administration," Tyler Coward, lead counsel for government affairs at the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, told Axios in an email Thursday.</p><ul><li>"Institutions must stand up for their rights now, or risk never getting them back again," he added.</li></ul><p><strong>Go deeper: </strong><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/22/harvard-trump-international-students-dhs" target="_blank">Trump admin nixes Harvard's ability to enroll international students</a></p>

Title: Lutnick: Trade deals are coming, higher prices aren't
Description: <p>Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick says he's convinced of two things: The U.S. will make a long list of <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/lutnick-tariffs-trump" target="_blank">trade deals</a> by mid-summer, and the <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/trump-tariffs-china" target="_blank">tariffs</a> forcing those deals won't raise retail prices.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong>Investors, business leaders and consumers are praying he's right.</p><hr><p><strong>Driving the news: </strong>Lutnick, a billionaire Wall Street CEO before entering government, was nothing but optimistic in an interview with Axios' Mike Allen at the Building the Future event in Washington.</p><ul><li>Asked how many of the U.S.'s 18 key trading partners would have a deal by the time a tariff pause ends July 8, he said, "I think most countries, we'll have an idea of what we want to do with them."</li></ul><p><strong>The big picture: </strong>Lutnick is at the forefront of the Trump administration's sweeping efforts to rewrite the rules of global trade, a campaign that has disrupted the <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/economy-tariffs-inflation-cleveland-fed-president" target="_blank">U.S.</a> and <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/22/trump-global-economy-tariffs-imf" target="_blank">international</a> economies and created deep uncertainty for <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/11/wall-street-jpmorgan-dimon-outlook-earnings" target="_blank">businesses</a> and <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/19/tariffs-consumer-economy-sentiment" target="_blank">consumers</a>.</p><ul><li>The president's argument: The U.S. has been treated unfairly by the world for decades, at the cost of valuable American jobs ‚Äî a situation that can only be fixed by a more aggressive approach.</li></ul><p><strong>Between the lines: </strong>Over the last few days, the single most important question about the tariffs has been what they'll do to the American consumer.</p><ul><li>Lutnick recently decried "silly arguments" that tariffs raise prices. A few days later, Walmart said they'd do exactly that, and a number of other companies have hinted at the same since. </li><li>The commerce secretary didn't flinch, though. "The president has to stand strong, and you can't fix things in a day, and that's still going, but I would expect that prices in America will be unaffected."</li></ul><p><strong>Reality check:</strong> Notwithstanding Lutnick's certainty, retail executives expect cost pressures to build week by week, with price increases getting much more noticeable by late June or early July.¬†</p><p><strong>The intrigue: </strong>While U.S. trade relations work through their biggest disruption in nearly a century, Lutnick and Trump are pushing a different incentive for foreign business leaders: a $5 million "gold card" that would confer permanent U.S. residency.</p><ul><li>The <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/trump-gold-card-lutnick" target="_blank">website</a>, trumpcard.gov, will launch within a week</li><li>"Everyone I meet who's not an American is going to want to buy the card if they have the fiscal capacity," he said.</li><li>"This is for people who can help America pay off its debt. Why wouldn't you want a Plan B that says, God forbid something bad happens, you come to the airport in America and the person in immigration says, 'Welcome home.'"</li></ul>

Title: Jony Ive hire is a big bet on hardware for OpenAI
Description: <p>With its <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/jony-ive-openai-io-acquisition" target="_blank">multibillion-dollar purchase</a> of Apple design legend Jony Ive's startup, OpenAI is doubling down on a bet that the AI revolution will birth a new generation of novel consumer devices.</p><p><strong>Why it matters:</strong> Just as the web first came to us on the personal computer and the cloud enabled the rise of the smartphone, OpenAI's gamble is that AI's role as <a href="https://www.axios.com/2023/02/17/chatgpt-ai-next-platform-tech" target="_blank">Silicon Valley's new platform</a> will demand a different kind of hardware ‚Äî and that Ive, who played a key role in designing the iPhone and other iconic Apple products, is the person to build it.</p><hr><p><strong>What they're saying: </strong>An <a href="https://openai.com/sam-and-jony/?asset=video" target="_blank">OpenAI promo video </a>features Ive and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman strolling through San Francisco's North Beach to meet for coffee at Francis Coppola's Zoetrope cafe.</p><ul><li>Ive tells Altman that we're still using "decades old" products, meaning PCs and smartphones, to connect with the "unimaginable technology" of today's AI ‚Äî "so it's just common sense" to work on "something beyond these legacy products."</li></ul><p><strong>Between the lines:</strong> Altman has long pursued a strategy of shaping AI through devices as well as software.</p><ul><li>He was an early investor in <a href="https://www.axios.com/2023/11/09/humane-ai-pin-orders-next-week" target="_blank">Humane</a>, whose Ai Pin device flopped, and is a co-founder of World (formerly Worldcoin), which is deploying its <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/01/sam-altman-world-biometric-us-rollout" target="_blank">eyeball-scanning Orbs</a> to verify human identity in a bot-filled world.</li><li>At OpenAI's first-ever developer conference in 2023, Altman <a href="https://www.axios.com/2023/11/06/open-ai-dev-day-chatgpt-custom" target="_self">told Axios</a> that major platform shifts usually usher in a new type of computing device. "If there's something amazing to do, we'll do it," he said.</li><li>Late last year, OpenAI <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2024/11/05/openai-hires-metas-former-orion-head-to-lead-its-robotics-efforts.html" target="_blank">relaunched</a> a hardware and robotics team, hiring former Meta executive Caitlin Kalinowski.</li><li>Ive and Altman announced last year that they were collaborating on a hardware side project but have been tight-lipped about what their startup, named io, is working on, though Altman told Axios in an onstage interview last year that it <a href="https://www.axios.com/2024/09/24/sam-altman-jony-ive-ai-device-phone" target="_blank">wouldn't be a smartphone</a>.</li><li>The company may be pursuing "headphones and other devices with cameras," <a href="https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/former-apple-design-guru-jony-ive-to-take-expansive-role-at-openai-5787f7da?st=UvZgB1&amp;reflink=article_copyURL_share" target="_blank">per the Wall Street Journal.</a></li></ul><p><strong>Altman loves a big bet,</strong> and this one is huge: billions in stock in exchange for Ive's talents and those of the rest of the team at io ‚Äî which includes three other veteran Apple design leaders.</p><p><strong>By the numbers:</strong> OpenAI said Wednesday it will pay $5 billion in stock to acquire the parts of io it doesn't already own. </p><ul><li>It already had a 23% stake in the company thanks to an exclusive partnership it signed in the fourth quarter of last year.</li><li>Once the deal closes, which is expected to happen later this summer, the 55-person team behind io will join OpenAI, to be led by Peter Welinder. (Kalinowski will now report to Welinder rather than Altman.)</li><li>Ive and his design firm, LoveFrom, will take on a major design role for OpenAI, though LoveFrom will remain independent and continue working on some other projects.</li></ul><p><strong>The big picture:</strong> Other big tech companies have also been investing in a post-smartphone hardware future.</p><ul><li>While investor interest in the metaverse has cooled, there's still a competitive market in VR headsets and a growing field of smart glasses as a delivery device for AI services.</li><li>Meta has its <a href="https://www.axios.com/2024/02/09/meta-ray-ban-smart-glasses-ai-review" target="_blank">Ray-Ban smart glasses</a>. Google demonstrated its own <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/google-ai-io-announcements-2025" target="_blank">prototype glasses</a>, which include a small display. And Apple is reportedly working on augmented-reality glasses, too.</li></ul><p><strong>The intrigue:</strong> OpenAI's deal further seals Ive's exile from Apple, which <a href="https://www.axios.com/2019/06/27/apple-design-chief-jony-ive-to-leave-later-this-year" target="_blank">started in 2019</a>, and fully ties him to an emerging competitor.</p><p><strong>Our thought bubble: </strong>Ive famously spent his career at Apple as Steve Jobs' creative partner.</p><ul><li>OpenAI's video presents the new Ive-Altman pairing as the natural successor to that team ‚Äî with Sam as the new Steve and Apple left behind as a peddler of "legacy products."</li></ul><p><strong>What's next:</strong> OpenAI said that it will share the first fruits of its new hardware efforts next year, though there's no promise that anything will be shipping that soon.</p>

Title: Retail heavyweights torn over how to handle tariff pain
Description: <p><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/15/walmart-store-prices-trump-tariffs" target="_blank">Prices are going up</a>, that's clear now ‚Äî but the nation's biggest retailers are taking very different approaches to what they say on the impact of tariffs publicly.</p><p><strong>Why it matters: </strong><a href="https://www.axios.com/economy/tariffs" target="_blank">President Trump's trade war</a> is stirring echoes of the inflation that took hold of the economy just three years ago.</p><hr><ul><li>Unlike the COVID era, the increase in prices was entirely foreseeable this time.</li></ul><p><strong>The big picture: </strong>Over the last week, the warning lights have started to flash.</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/15/walmart-trump-tariffs-china-trade" target="_blank">Walmart</a>, the world's largest retailer, said last week it couldn't hold the line anymore and would have to raise some prices.</li><li><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/target-stock-sales-tariff-impact" target="_blank">Target</a> said it would "offset the vast majority" of <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/15/walmart-store-prices-trump-tariffs" target="_blank">tariff impacts to consumers</a> and remain "price competitive."</li><li><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/20/home-depot-stock-prices-tariffs" target="_blank">Home Depot</a> doesn't plan to increase prices "broadly" because of tariffs, but said some items might disappear from store shelves.</li><li>Those comments came after the CEOs of all three met with Trump in April and<strong> </strong><a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/23/trump-economy-tariffs-china-powell" target="_self">warned</a> the president that tariffs would soon <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/04/26/trump-tariffs-shortages-prices-china-products" target="_self">lead to empty shelves, higher prices</a> and shortages.</li></ul><p><strong>State of play: </strong><a href="https://www.axios.com/politics-policy/donald-trump" target="_blank">Trump</a> has, for years, steadfastly insisted that Americans don't pay for tariffs ‚Äî the costs, somehow, are absorbed overseas.</p><ul><li>But over the weekend, he demanded <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/17/trump-walmart-tariffs" target="_blank">Walmart "eat the tariffs</a>," which <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/18/trump-tariffs-bessent-walmart-prices" target="_blank">Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent acknowledged</a> the company could only do for so long.</li><li>It was, in its way, a <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/19/trump-tariffs-who-pays" target="_blank">concession</a> of the reality that almost all of the tariff cost is borne domestically. (A reality backed up by the government's <a href="https://www.apricitas.io/p/trumps-retreat-still-leaves-tariffs?img=https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F817fe5d1-d6fc-45a8-a7ca-7e7bc140a2b0_2886x1843.png&amp;open=false" target="_blank">own data</a>, per a recent Apricitas Economics note.)</li></ul><p><strong>Zoom in: </strong>Target and Home Depot both spoke about pricing this week, notably after Trump came down on Walmart.</p><ul><li>We don't see broad-based price increases for our customers at all going forward," Billy Bastek, Home Depot's executive vice president of merchandising, said Tuesday.</li><li>Target was less certain: "We have many levers to use in mitigating the impact of tariffs and price is the very last resort," CEO Brian Cornell said Wednesday.</li></ul><p><strong>Between the lines: </strong>Zacks Investment Research analyst Sheraz Mian told Axios Twin Cities' Nick Halter he doubts Target will be able to fully absorb the tariffs.</p><ul><li>"They don't want to publicly acknowledge it and get into the unfavorable kind of political limelight by speaking the truth," Mian said.</li></ul><p><strong>The intrigue: </strong>Americans seem to only have a vague grasp of the mechanics of tariffs, even if they get the ultimate impact.</p><ul><li>A new <a href="https://email.zappistore.com/hubfs/Tariff%20Survey%20Report.pdf" target="_blank">report</a> from consumer insights platform Zappi finds just 22% of people fully understand how tariffs affect the prices of goods ‚Äî and only 20% think their household is ready to absorb those higher prices.</li><li>But one way or another, they get <em>something</em> is coming ‚Äî the latest University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey found year-ahead inflation expectations surging to 7.3%, the highest since the early 1980s.</li><li>"If these pre-tariff strategies have run their course, we're about to see some changes in prices, and then we're going to learn how consumers are going to respond to that," Atlanta Fed president <a href="https://www.axios.com/2025/05/21/tariffs-prices-kids-shoes" target="_blank">Raphael Bostic</a> told reporters at a conference this week.</li></ul><p><strong>The bottom line:</strong> Customers may see certain items exiled from store shelves if they're impacted too much by tariffs.</p><ul><li>"There'll be some things that don't make sense that just end up going away," Home Depot's Bastek said.</li></ul>

Title: Patients from Nottingham killer's NHS trust carried out stabbings weeks before attack
Description: Two men under the care of the same NHS trust as Valdo Calocane carried out stabbings weeks before the Nottingham attacks.

Title: Why did the government sign the Chagos deal now?
Description: A deal to hand Mauritius the Chagos Islands and lease back a key military base has been months in the making.

<p style="text-align: left;">Á´ôÂú®ÁõàÂà©ÁöÑÊñ∞Ëµ∑ÁÇπ‰∏äÔºåÈòøÈáåÂ§ßÊñáÂ®±ÊâìÁÆóÈóØÂá∫‰∏ÄÁï™Êñ∞Â§©Âú∞„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">‚Äú Êú™Êù•ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰ºöÂùöÂÆö‚ÄòÂÜÖÂÆπ+ÁßëÊäÄ‚ÄôÂèåËΩÆÈ©±Âä®ÊàòÁï•Ôºå‰∏∫Áî®Êà∑Êèê‰æõÁ∫ø‰∏ä„ÄÅÁ∫ø‰∏ãÂÖ®Âú∫ÊôØÂ®±‰πê‰ΩìÈ™å„ÄÇ‚ÄùÂê¥ÂÄ©Ë°®Á§∫ÔºåÂ§ßÊñáÂ®±ÂêçÂ≠óËôΩÂèòÔºå‰∏öÂä°ÊàòÁï•‰∏çÁßªÔºåÊú™Êù•Â∞Ü‰ª•AIÂíåÁßëÊäÄ‰∏∫ÊäìÊâãÔºåËÆ©ÊñáÂ®±Ë°å‰∏öËâØÊÄßÂèëÂ±ïÔºåÊâìÈÄ†‰∏ÄËâòÁ©øË∂äÂë®ÊúüÁöÑÊñáÂ®±ËØ∫‰∫öÊñπËàü„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">ÁÑ∂ËÄåÔºå‰∏çÊñ≠Ê∂åÁé∞ÁöÑÂÜÖÂÆπÂΩ¢ÂºèÂè†Âä†Âø´ÈÄüËø≠‰ª£ÁöÑAIÊäÄÊúØÔºåÂØπÊñáÂ®±Ë°å‰∏öÊèêÂá∫‰∫ÜÊõ¥È´òÁöÑË¶ÅÊ±ÇÔºåÈòøÈáåÂ§ßÊñáÂ®±Ë¶ÅÊÉ≥ÂÅöÂá∫Êõ¥Â§ßÁöÑÊàêÁª©ÔºåËøòÈúÄË¶ÅÊãøÂá∫ÁúüÊú¨‰∫ã„ÄÇ</p>
<h2 style="text-align: left;">Ê±ÇÂèò</h2>
<p style="text-align: left;">Êó†ËÆ∫ÊòØÂêçÂ≠óËøòÊòØÂØπÂ§ñÂΩ¢Ë±°ÔºåÈòøÈáåÂ§ßÊñáÂ®±Ê≠£Âú®‰ª•ÂÖ®Êñ∞Èù¢Ë≤åÁ§∫‰∫∫„ÄÇÈòøÈáåÁöÑÂä®Áâ©Âõ≠ÂÆ∂ÊóèÔºå‰ªéÊ≠§Â§ö‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ËôéÈ≤∏„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">‰∏Ä‰ΩçÈòøÈáåÂÜÖÈÉ®‰∫∫Â£´ÂØπÂçéÂ∞îË°óËßÅÈóªË°®Á§∫ÔºåËôéÈ≤∏Ë∫´ÂΩ¢Â∫ûÂ§ß‰ΩÜÁÅµÊ¥ªËÅ™ÊòéÔºåËÉΩÈÄÇÂ∫îÂêÑÁßçÂ§çÊùÇÁéØÂ¢ÉÔºåÊòØÂÖ∏ÂûãÁöÑÁæ§Â±ÖÂä®Áâ©ÔºåËÄå‰∏îÊã•Êúâ‰∏∞Ê≤õÁöÑÊÉÖÊÑüÔºåÂØπ‰∫∫ÈùûÂ∏∏ÂèãÂ•ΩÔºåÈÄâÊã©ËôéÈ≤∏ÂæàÂ•ëÂêàÂ§ßÊñáÂ®±ÊâÄËøΩÊ±ÇÁöÑÁêÜÂøµ„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Âê¥ÂÄ©Ë°®Á§∫ÔºåÊñáÂ®±Ë°å‰∏öÂÜÖÂÆπÊäïËµÑÂ§ßÔºåÂà∂‰ΩúÂë®ÊúüÈïøÔºåÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÁ©øË∂äÂë®ÊúüÔºå‰∏ç‰ªÖËÄÉÈ™åÂØπÊ∂àË¥πËÄÖÈúÄÊ±ÇÁöÑÊ¥ûÂØüÔºåÊõ¥ËÄÉÈ™åÈÄöËøáÁ≤æÁªÜÂåñËøêËê•ÂØπÊäïÂÖ•Âíå‰∫ßÂá∫ÁöÑÂπ≥Ë°°„ÄÇÂ•πÂ∏åÊúõÔºå‰ª•AIÊäÄÊúØ‰∏∫ÊäìÊâãÔºåÂÆûÁé∞ÈôçÊú¨Â¢ûÊïàÔºåÊâìÈÄ†‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï∞Êô∫„ÄÅÂÖ±Áîü„ÄÅÂø´‰πêÁöÑÊñáÂ®±ÁîüÊÄÅ„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">ÊâÄË∞ì‚ÄúÊï∞Êô∫‚ÄùÔºåÊòØËá¥Âäõ‰∫éËÆ©AIÁúüÊ≠£ËûçÂÖ•ÊñáÂ®±Ë°å‰∏öÁöÑË°ÄËÑâÔºåÂª∫ËÆæ‰∏Ä‰∏™AIÊó∂‰ª£ÁöÑÂÖ®Êñ∞Â®±‰πêÁâàÂõæ„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">‰∏äËø∞Áü•ÊÉÖ‰∫∫Â£´Ë°®Á§∫ÔºåÈòøÈáåÂ§ßÊñáÂ®±ÂÜÖÈÉ®Ôºå‰ªéÂÜÖÂÆπÁîü‰∫ßÁ´ØÂíå‰ΩìÈ™åÊúçÂä°Á´ØÈÉΩËøõË°å‰∫ÜAIÈ©±Âä®ÁöÑÂ∞ùËØïÔºåAI‰πüÂ∑≤Âá∫Áé∞Âú®ÂêÑÁ±ª‰ΩøÁî®Âú∫ÊôØ‰∏≠ÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÔºåAIËæÖÂä©ÁîüÊàêÊï∞Â≠óËµÑ‰∫ßÔºåAIËæÖÂä©ÊèêÂçáËôöÊãüÊãçÊëÑËôöÂÆûÊ†°ÂáÜÊïàÁéáÔºåAIËæÖÂä©ÊèêÂçáË∂ÖÈ´òÊ∏ÖÂÜÖÂÆπÁöÑÂà∂‰ΩúÊïàÁéáÁ≠â„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">ÊçÆÂê¥ÂÄ©‰ªãÁªçÔºåÂú®ËôöÊãüÊãçÊëÑÈ¢ÜÂüüÔºåÈòøÈáåÂ§ßÊñáÂ®±Â∑≤ÁªèÂú®Â§ö‰∏™ÂüéÂ∏ÇËêΩÂú∞Â∏ß‰∫´Êï∞Â≠óÂΩ±Ê£öÔºåÊ∑±Â∫¶ÊîØÊåÅ‰∫ÜÂ§öÈÉ®SÁ∫ßÂâßÈõÜÂíåÈô¢Á∫øÁîµÂΩ±ÁöÑÊãçÊëÑÔºõÊ≠§Â§ñÔºåÂÖ¨Âè∏Ëøò‰∏∫ÁâáÊñπÊâìÈÄ†‰∫ÜÂÆ£ÂèëÊúçÂä°Âπ≥Âè∞ÁÅØÂ°îÔºå‰∏∫Âêà‰Ωú‰ºô‰º¥ËäÇÁúÅ‰∫Ü20%‰ª•‰∏äÁöÑÂÆ£ÂèëÈ¢ÑÁÆó„ÄÇ</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">3ÊúàÔºåÁü•ËØÜ‰∫ßÊùÉÂàÜÊûêÊú∫ÊûÑIPRdailyÂèëÂ∏É„ÄäÂÖ®ÁêÉËôöÊãüÊãçÊëÑÊäÄÊúØÂèëÊòé‰∏ìÂà©ÊéíË°åÊ¶úÔºàTOP 30Ôºâ„ÄãÔºåÊù•Ëá™‰∏≠ÂõΩÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥‰∏ìÂà©Áî≥ËØ∑Âç†ÊØî52%Ôºå‰ºòÈÖ∑‰ª•80‰ª∂ËôöÊãüÊãçÊëÑÂèëÊòé‰∏ìÂà©‰ΩçÂàóÂÖ®ÁêÉÊ¶úÈ¶ñ„ÄÇÂêåÊúüÔºåÈòøÈáåÂ§ßÊñáÂ®±ÂèëÂ∏É‰∫ÜËôöÊãüÊãçÊëÑËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à5.0ÁâàÊú¨ÔºåÂèØÂ§ßÂπÖÊèêÂçáÂΩ±ËßÜÂà∂‰ΩúÊïàÁéá„ÄÇ</p>
